FedVQCS: Federated Learning via
Vector Quantized Compressed Sensing

Yongjeong Oh, , Yo-Seb Jeon, ,
Mingzhe Chen, , and Walid Saad Yongjeong Oh is with the Department of Electrical Engineering, POSTECH, Pohang, Gyeongbuk 37673, Republic of Korea (e-mail: yongjeongoh@postech.ac.kr).Yo-Seb Jeon is with the Department of Electrical Engineering, POSTECH, Pohang, Gyeongbuk 37673, Republic of Korea. He is also with the Institute for Convergence Research and Education in Advanced Technology, Yonsei University, Incheon 21983, Republic of Korea (e-mail: yoseb.jeon@postech.ac.kr).Mingzhe Chen is with the Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering and Institute for Data Science and Computing, University of Miami, Coral Gables, FL 33146, USA (e-mail: mingzhe.chen@miami.edu).Walid Saad is with the Wireless@VT, Bradley Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Virginia Tech, Arlington, VA 22203, USA (e-mail: walids@vt.edu).
Abstract

In this paper, a new communication-efficient federated learning (FL) framework is proposed, inspired by vector quantized compressed sensing. The basic strategy of the proposed framework is to compress the local model update at each device by applying dimensionality reduction followed by vector quantization. Subsequently, the global model update is reconstructed at a parameter server by applying a sparse signal recovery algorithm to the aggregation of the compressed local model updates. By harnessing the benefits of both dimensionality reduction and vector quantization, the proposed framework effectively reduces the communication overhead of local update transmissions. Both the design of the vector quantizer and the key parameters for the compression are optimized so as to minimize the reconstruction error of the global model update under the constraint of wireless link capacity. By considering the reconstruction error, the convergence rate of the proposed framework is also analyzed for a non-convex loss function. Simulation results on the MNIST and FEMNIST datasets demonstrate that the proposed framework provides more than a 2.4%percent\% increase in classification accuracy compared to state-of-the-art FL frameworks when the communication overhead of the local model update transmission is 0.1 bit per local model entry.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, distributed learning, quantized compressed sensing, vector quantization, dimensionality reduction

I Introduction

Federated learning (FL) is a distributed machine learning technique which aims at training a global model on a parameter server (PS) by collaborating with distributed wireless devices, each with its own local training dataset [1, 2]. In a typical FL framework, each device updates its local model based on the local training dataset and then sends a local model update to the PS [2]. After the transmission from the devices, the PS updates its global model by aggregating the local model updates sent by the devices and then distributes the updated global model to the devices. This two-step training process continues until the global model at the PS converges. The above FL framework can help preserve the privacy of the data generated by the devices. Hence, it has drawn great attention as a privacy-preserving alternative to centralized machine learning [3, 4, 5, 6, 7]. While FL offers an important benefit in terms of data privacy, bringing this technique into real-world applications also faces several challenges. One major such challenge is the significant communication overhead required for transmitting the local model updates from the wireless devices to the PS because the wireless links connecting them may have limited capacity in practical communication systems. This challenge becomes critical when the dimensionality of the local model updates is much larger than the capacity of the wireless links. For example, when the wireless link capacity is 202020 Mbps and the global model is ResNet-181818 in [8] with 1.1×1071.1superscript1071.1\times 10^{7} trainable parameters, transmitting the local model update for 100100100 times with 101010 devices takes about 1.8×1041.8superscript1041.8\times 10^{4} seconds. Such long communication times may not be acceptable for low-power devices and practical FL applications that often must operate at much lower latency.

I-A Prior Works

To address the above challenge, communication-efficient FL via local model update compression was extensively studied. The basic idea in these prior works is to apply lossy compression to the local model updates, in order to reduce the communication overhead required for transmitting these updates. A representative approach in this direction is the scalar quantization approach studied in [9, 10, 11, 12], in which the entries of the local model update are independently quantized by a scalar quantizer. By extending this approach, a vector quantization approach for communication-efficient FL was also studied in [13, 14, 15]. In this approach, a partition of each local model update is quantized by a vector quantizer. The common limitation of the quantization-only approach, however, is that significant quantization error is inevitable when the communication overhead of the local model update transmission must be less than one bit per local model entry.

Recently, to overcome the limitation of the quantization-only approach, communication-efficient FL via quantized compressed sensing (QCS) has been explored in [16, 17, 18]. A key motivation in this approach is the sparsity of the local model update, obtained either naturally or by applying sparsification [19, 20, 21, 22, 23, 24]. To exploit this sparsity, the basic premise of the QCS approach is to project the local model updates onto a lower dimensional space as in compressed sensing (CS) before they are quantized. Because of the ensuing dimensionality reduction, this approach can further reduce the communication overhead of the local update transmissions when compared with the quantization-only approach. A QCS-based compression method with one-bit quantization was studied in [16] and [17], in which the entries of the local model update after dimensionality reduction were independently quantized by a one-bit scalar quantizer. This method was extended to the compression with multi-bit quantization in [18] which allows greater flexibility regarding the number of scalar quantization bits. The work in [18] demonstrated that the use of multi-bit quantization provides a better tradeoff between communication efficiency and FL performance when compared with the one-bit quantization [18]. The existing QCS-based compression methods, however, only consider scalar quantization which is generally inferior to vector quantization in terms of quantization error [25]; thereby, the compression error of these methods becomes problematic as the level of the compression increases. To our best knowledge, local model update compression that harnesses the benefits of both vector quantization and dimensionality reduction has never been studied before, despite its potential for improving the communication efficiency of FL and mitigating the compression error of the local model updates.

I-B Contributions

The main contribution of this paper is a novel communication-efficient FL framework that leverages, for the first time, both vector quantization and CS-based dimensionality reduction to compress local model updates at the wireless devices. We also propose a promising strategy for reconstructing the global model update at the PS from the compressed local model updates. More importantly, we minimize the reconstruction error at the PS by optimizing both the design of the vector quantizer and the key parameters for the compression and, then, we analyze the convergence rate of our framework with consideration of the reconstruction error. In summary, our major contributions include the following:

  • •

    We present a communication-efficient FL framework via vector quantized compressed sensing (VQCS), dubbed FedVQCS. In this framework, we compress each local model update by reducing its dimensionality based on CS and, then, quantizing a low-dimensional local model update by using a vector quantizer. For accurate but efficient reconstruction of the global model update at the PS, we aggregate a group of the compressed local model updates and, then, estimate the aggregated model update by applying a sparse signal recovery algorithm. By harnessing the benefits of both dimensionality reduction and vector quantization, FedVQCS significantly reduces the communication overhead required for transmitting the local model updates at the wireless devices.

  • •

    We optimize the design of the vector quantizer used for the local update compression strategy of FedVQCS. A key feature of our compression strategy is that the local model update after the CS-based dimensionality reduction can be modeled as an independent and identically distributed (IID) Gaussian random vector by the central limit theorem. By utilizing this feature, we derive the optimal shape and gain quantizers for an IID Gaussian random vector based on the Lloyd–Max algorithm [26] and Grassmanian codebook [27], respectively. We also derive the optimal bit allocation between the shape and gain quantizers by characterizing the mean-squared-error (MSE) performance of these quantizers.

  • •

    We optimize the key design parameters of the local update compression strategy of FedVQCS, that include: (i) the number of quantization bits, (ii) sparsity level, and (iii) dimensionality reduction ratio. Unlike previous works where these parameters were heuristically determined as hyper-parameters, we analytically determine the best set of parameters for minimizing the reconstruction error of the global model update at the PS under a capacity constraint. A prominent feature of our parameter optimization is that it can be performed locally at each device without information exchange among the devices.

  • •

    We analyze the convergence rate of FedVQCS, taking into account all errors that should be considered in the QCS-based FL framework, including sparsification errors of the local model update at the devices and reconstruction errors of the global model update at the PS. Our analysis demonstrates that FedVQCS is guaranteed to converge to a stationary point of a smooth loss function at the rate of 𝒪​(1T)𝒪1𝑇\mathcal{O}\big{(}\frac{1}{\sqrt{T}}\big{)}, where T𝑇T is the number of total iterations of the stochastic gradient descent (SGD) algorithm. Our analysis also shows that the upper bound of the convergence rate decreases as the MSE of the global model update reconstructed at the PS reduces, implying that our parameter optimization contributes to improving the convergence rate of FL.

  • •

    Using simulations, we demonstrate the superiority of FedVQCS over state-of-the-art FL frameworks for an image classification task using the MNIST dataset [28] and the FEMNIST dataset [29]. Our simulation results demonstrate that FedVQCS provides more than a 2.4%percent\% increase in classification accuracy compared to the state-of-the-art FL frameworks when the communication overhead of the local model update transmission is 0.1 bit per local model entry. Meanwhile, the results on the MNIST dataset demonstrate that FedVQCS with a 0.1-bit overhead per local model entry yields only a 2%percent\% decrease in classification accuracy when compared with the case that performs no local update compression. The effectiveness of the parameter optimization of FedVQCS is also verified in terms of classification accuracy.

In our preliminary work [30], we introduced a communication-efficient FL framework based on VQCS including the optimal design of the vector quantizer. We extend this preliminary work by making important progress on improving and analyzing the VQCS-based FL framework. First of all, we newly provide the parameter optimization for the local model update compression, which is critical for minimizing the reconstruction error of the global model update at the PS, as will be demonstrated in Sec. V. Furthermore, we present the convergence analysis of the VQCS-based FL framework to theoretically justify the effectiveness of this framework, which was not explored in [30].

The remainder of the paper is organized as follows. In Sec. II, we first introduce a wireless FL system considered in the paper. We then present a typical FL framework and its challenge. In Sec. III, we present the proposed FedVQCS framework, which addresses the above challenge by leveraging the idea of VQCS. In Sec. IV, we optimize a quantizer design and key parameters of FedVQCS and analyze its convergence rate. In Sec. V, we provide simulation results to verify the superiority of the proposed framework. Finally, in Sec. VI, we present our conclusions and future research directions.

II System Model

Consider a wireless FL system in which a PS trains a global model by collaborating with a set 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K} of K𝐾K wireless devices over wireless links with limited capacity. The data samples for training the global model are assumed to be distributed over the wireless devices only, while the PS does not have direct access to them. Let 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k} be the local training dataset available at device k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\in\mathcal{K}. The global model at the PS is assumed to be represented by a parameter vector 𝒘∈ℝN¯𝒘superscriptℝ¯𝑁\boldsymbol{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{\bar{N}}, where N¯¯𝑁\bar{N} is the number of global model parameters. The goal of FL is to find the best parameter vector that minimizes the global loss function, defined as

where f​(𝒘;𝒖)𝑓𝒘𝒖f(\boldsymbol{w};\boldsymbol{u}) is a loss function that measures how well the global model with the parameter vector 𝒘𝒘\boldsymbol{w} fits one particular data sample 𝒖∈𝒟k𝒖subscript𝒟𝑘\boldsymbol{u}\in\mathcal{D}_{k}, and 𝒟=∪k𝒟k𝒟subscript𝑘subscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}=\cup_{k}\mathcal{D}_{k}. II-A A Typical FL Framework

A typical FL approach for minimizing the global loss function in (2) involves alternating between local model update at wireless devices and global model update at the PS in each communication round, as explained in [2].

II-A1 Local model update at wireless devices

In the local model update process, each wireless device updates a local parameter vector based on its own local training dataset. Then each device sends a local model update (i.e., the difference between the parameter vectors before and after the local update) to the PS. Let 𝒘(t)∈ℝN¯superscript𝒘𝑡superscriptℝ¯𝑁\boldsymbol{w}^{(t)}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{\bar{N}} be the parameter vector shared by the devices at communication round t∈{1,…,T}𝑡1…𝑇t\in\{1,\ldots,T\}, where T𝑇T is the total number of communication rounds. Assume that every device employs a mini-batch SGD algorithm with E≥1𝐸1E\geq 1 local iterations for updating the parameter vector 𝒘(t)superscript𝒘𝑡\boldsymbol{w}^{(t)}. Then the updated parameter vector at device k𝑘k after E≥1𝐸1E\geq 1 local iterations is given by

𝒘k(t,e+1)=𝒘k(t,e)−η(t)​∇Fk(t,e)​(𝒘k(t,e)),subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡𝑒1𝑘subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡𝑒𝑘superscript𝜂𝑡∇superscriptsubscript𝐹𝑘𝑡𝑒subscriptsuperscript𝒘𝑡𝑒𝑘\displaystyle\boldsymbol{w}^{(t,e+1)}_{k}=\boldsymbol{w}^{(t,e)}_{k}-\eta^{(t)}\nabla F_{k}^{(t,e)}\big{(}\boldsymbol{w}^{(t,e)}_{k}\big{)}, (3)

II-A2 Global model update at the PS

In the global model update process, the PS updates a global parameter vector by aggregating the local model updates sent by K𝐾K devices. Then the PS broadcasts the updated parameter vector to these devices. Under the assumption of perfect reception of K𝐾K local model updates, the PS can reconstruct the global model update, defined as

𝒈𝒦(t)=∑k=1Kρk​𝒈k(t),superscriptsubscript𝒈𝒦𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝜌𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒈𝑘𝑡\displaystyle\boldsymbol{g}_{\mathcal{K}}^{(t)}=\sum_{k=1}^{K}\rho_{k}\boldsymbol{g}_{k}^{(t)}, (6)

where ρk≜∑e=1E|𝒟k(t,e)|∑j=1K∑e=1E|𝒟j(t,e)|≜subscript𝜌𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑒1𝐸superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘𝑡𝑒superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑒1𝐸superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑗𝑡𝑒\rho_{k}\triangleq\frac{\sum_{e=1}^{E}|\mathcal{D}_{k}^{(t,e)}|}{\sum_{j=1}^{K}\sum_{e=1}^{E}|\mathcal{D}_{j}^{(t,e)}|} is invariant in each communication round. If the PS employs the SGD algorithm for updating the parameter vector 𝒘(t)superscript𝒘𝑡\boldsymbol{w}^{(t)}, then the updated parameter vector in round t𝑡t will be given by

𝒘(t+1)=𝒘(t)−γ(t)​𝒈𝒦(t),superscript𝒘𝑡1superscript𝒘𝑡superscript𝛾𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒈𝒦𝑡\displaystyle\boldsymbol{w}^{(t+1)}=\boldsymbol{w}^{(t)}-\gamma^{(t)}\boldsymbol{g}_{\mathcal{K}}^{(t)}, (7)

where γ(t)superscript𝛾𝑡\gamma^{(t)} is a global learning rate. Then the PS broadcasts 𝒘(t+1)superscript𝒘𝑡1\boldsymbol{w}^{(t+1)} to the wireless devices, which triggers the start of the local model update process in round t+1𝑡1t+1.

II-B Key Challenge in Wireless FL

A major challenge in realizing the FL framework in Sec. II-A is the significant communication overhead required for transmitting the local model updates from the wireless devices to the PS because the wireless links connecting them may have limited capacity in practical communication systems. This challenge can be mitigated by applying lossy compression to the local model updates, but such a compression approach leads to an inevitable error in the global model update reconstructed at the PS. Moreover, in general, the higher the level of compression at the wireless devices, the larger the reconstruction error at the PS. Therefore, it is essential to develop a rigorous compression strategy for local model updates that provides a considerable reduction in the communication overhead while also minimizing the reconstruction error at the PS.

III Proposed FedVQCS framework

In this section, we present a communication-efficient FL framework, called FedVQCS, that can reduce the communication overhead for transmitting local model updates at the wireless devices while also enabling an accurate reconstruction of the global model update at the PS.

III-A Overview of FedVQCS

The basic strategy of FedVQCS is to compress the local model updates at the wireless devices by leveraging both vector quantization and CS-based dimensionality reduction while reconstructing the global model update at the PS via sparse signal recovery. The high-level procedure of FedVQCS is illustrated in Fig. 1 and described below.

III-A1 Compression of the local model updates

In each communication round, each device divides its local model update into B𝐵B111The number of blocks B𝐵B is pre-determined at the PS before the beginning of the training process according to the computational power of the PS. blocks, each of which has a length of N=N¯B𝑁¯𝑁𝐵N=\frac{\bar{N}}{B}222In practice, this process can be realized by randomly shuffling local model update entries and then dividing blocks in order. The information about random shuffle can be expressed as a random seed number that can be shared between the PS and devices before the beginning of the training process.. Let 𝒈k(t,b)∈ℝNsuperscriptsubscript𝒈𝑘𝑡𝑏superscriptℝ𝑁\boldsymbol{g}_{k}^{(t,b)}\in\mathbb{R}^{N} be the b𝑏b-th block of 𝒈k(t)superscriptsubscript𝒈𝑘𝑡\boldsymbol{g}_{k}^{(t)}, and we refer to this vector as the b𝑏b-th local block update of device k𝑘k in round t𝑡t. Each device compresses these B𝐵B local block updates in parallel by applying a local block compression process denoted by a function 𝖡𝗅𝗄𝖢𝗈𝗆𝗉​(⋅)𝖡𝗅𝗄𝖢𝗈𝗆𝗉⋅{\sf BlkComp}(\cdot). The motivation behind this block-wise compression is to reduce the computational complexity for reconstructing the global model update at the PS, as considered in [18]. The compressed local block updates are encoded into digital bits and then transmitted to the PS through wireless links.

III-A2 Reconstruction of the global model update

In each communication round, the PS reconstructs a global model update from the compressed local model updates sent by the wireless devices. Let 𝒈𝒦(t,b)=∑k=1Kρk​𝒈k(t,b)superscriptsubscript𝒈𝒦𝑡𝑏superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝜌𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒈𝑘𝑡𝑏\boldsymbol{g}_{\mathcal{K}}^{(t,b)}=\sum_{k=1}^{K}\rho_{k}\boldsymbol{g}_{k}^{(t,b)} be the b𝑏b-th global block update in round t𝑡t which is the aggregation of the local block updates sent by K𝐾K devices. The PS first reconstructs 𝒈𝒦(t,b)superscriptsubscript𝒈𝒦𝑡𝑏\boldsymbol{g}_{\mathcal{K}}^{(t,b)} for every block b∈{1,…,B}𝑏1…𝐵b\in\{1,\ldots,B\}, by applying a global block reconstruction process denoted by a function 𝖡𝗅𝗄𝖱𝖾𝖼𝗈𝗇𝗌𝗍​(⋅)𝖡𝗅𝗄𝖱𝖾𝖼𝗈𝗇𝗌𝗍⋅{\sf BlkReconst}(\cdot). The PS then concatenates the reconstructed block updates to construct the global model update. This process is expressed as 𝒈^𝒦(t)=𝖢𝗈𝗇𝖼𝖺𝗍𝖾𝗇𝖺𝗍𝖾​({𝒈^𝒦(t,b)}b=1B)superscriptsubscript^𝒈𝒦𝑡𝖢𝗈𝗇𝖼𝖺𝗍𝖾𝗇𝖺𝗍𝖾superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript^𝒈𝒦𝑡𝑏𝑏1𝐵\hat{\boldsymbol{g}}_{\mathcal{K}}^{(t)}={\sf Concatenate}(\{\hat{\boldsymbol{g}}_{\mathcal{K}}^{(t,b)}\}_{b=1}^{B}), where 𝒈^𝒦(t,b)superscriptsubscript^𝒈𝒦𝑡𝑏\hat{\boldsymbol{g}}_{\mathcal{K}}^{(t,b)} is the reconstruction of 𝒈𝒦(t,b)superscriptsubscript𝒈𝒦𝑡𝑏{\boldsymbol{g}}_{\mathcal{K}}^{(t,b)} determined by the global block reconstruction process.

III-A3 Summary

The overall procedures of FedVQCS are summarized in Procedure 1, while the local block compression and global block reconstruction processes are summarized in Procedure 2 and Procedure 3, respectively. In the remainder of this section, we elaborate more on the local block compression process (see Sec. III-B) and the global block reconstruction process (see Sec. III-C). Note that FedVQCS can also be combined with other FL frameworks such as [31, 32, 33] for further performance improvement.

III-B Compression of Local Block Update

The local block compression process of FedVQCS consists of three steps: (i) sparsification, (ii) dimensionality reduction, and (iii) vector quantization, as summarized in Procedure 2. The details of each step performed by device k𝑘k for block b𝑏b in round t𝑡t are elaborated below.

III-B1 Sparsification

In the sparsification step, each local block update is sparsified by nullifying all but the most significant Sksubscript𝑆𝑘S_{k} entries in terms of their magnitudes, where Sk<Nsubscript𝑆𝑘𝑁S_{k}<N is a sparsity level chosen by device k𝑘k. To compensate for the information loss during the sparsification, the nullified entries are added to the local block update in the next communication round, as done in [22] and [23]. With this compensation strategy, the local block update that needs to be sparsified at device k𝑘k is expressed as

𝒈¯k(t,b)=𝒈k(t,b)+𝚫k(t−1,b),superscriptsubscript¯𝒈𝑘𝑡𝑏superscriptsubscript𝒈𝑘𝑡𝑏superscriptsubscript𝚫𝑘𝑡1𝑏\displaystyle\bar{\boldsymbol{g}}_{k}^{(t,b)}={\boldsymbol{g}}_{k}^{(t,b)}+{\boldsymbol{\Delta}}_{k}^{(t-1,b)}, (8)

where 𝚫k(t,b)∈ℝNsuperscriptsubscript𝚫𝑘𝑡𝑏superscriptℝ𝑁{\boldsymbol{\Delta}}_{k}^{(t,b)}\in\mathbb{R}^{{N}} is a residual vector stored by device k𝑘k for block b𝑏b in round t𝑡t. As a result, the local block update after the sparsification is denoted by 𝒈~k(t,b)=𝖲𝗉𝖺𝗋𝗌𝖾​(𝒈¯k(t,b))superscriptsubscript~𝒈𝑘𝑡𝑏𝖲𝗉𝖺𝗋𝗌𝖾superscriptsubscript¯𝒈𝑘𝑡𝑏\tilde{\boldsymbol{g}}_{k}^{(t,b)}={\sf Sparse}(\bar{\boldsymbol{g}}_{k}^{(t,b)}) which has only Sksubscript𝑆𝑘S_{k} nonzero entries. Then, the residual vector is updated as

𝚫k(t,b)=𝒈¯k(t,b)−𝖲𝗉𝖺𝗋𝗌𝖾​(𝒈¯k(t,b)).superscriptsubscript𝚫𝑘𝑡𝑏superscriptsubscript¯𝒈𝑘𝑡𝑏𝖲𝗉𝖺𝗋𝗌𝖾superscriptsubscript¯𝒈𝑘𝑡𝑏\displaystyle{\boldsymbol{\Delta}}_{k}^{(t,b)}=\bar{\boldsymbol{g}}_{k}^{(t,b)}-{\sf Sparse}(\bar{\boldsymbol{g}}_{k}^{(t,b)}). (9)

Our sparsification step is summarized in Steps 1–3 of Procedure 2.

III-B2 Dimensionality reduction

In the dimensionality reduction step, each local block update after the sparsification is projected onto a low-dimensional space as in CS [34]. In other words, the dimension of the sparsified local block update 𝒈~k(t,b)superscriptsubscript~𝒈𝑘𝑡𝑏\tilde{\boldsymbol{g}}_{k}^{(t,b)} is reduced based on the CS theory, as illustrated in Fig. 2. Let Rk=NMk≥1subscript𝑅𝑘𝑁subscript𝑀𝑘1R_{k}=\frac{N}{M_{k}}\geq 1 be a dimensionality reduction ratio chosen by device k𝑘k, where Mk≤Nsubscript𝑀𝑘𝑁M_{k}\leq N is the dimension after projection. Then, the compressed local block update 𝒙k(t,b)∈ℝMksuperscriptsubscript𝒙𝑘𝑡𝑏superscriptℝsubscript𝑀𝑘{\boldsymbol{x}}_{k}^{(t,b)}\in\mathbb{R}^{M_{k}} is obtained as

𝒙k(t,b)=αk(t,b)​𝑨Rk​𝒈~k(t,b),superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑘𝑡𝑏superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘𝑡𝑏subscript𝑨subscript𝑅𝑘superscriptsubscript~𝒈𝑘𝑡𝑏\displaystyle{\boldsymbol{x}}_{k}^{(t,b)}=\alpha_{k}^{(t,b)}{\boldsymbol{A}}_{R_{k}}\tilde{\boldsymbol{g}}_{k}^{(t,b)}, (10)

where αk(t,b)∈ℝsuperscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘𝑡𝑏ℝ\alpha_{k}^{(t,b)}\in\mathbb{R} is a scaling factor, and 𝑨Rk∈ℝMk×Nsubscript𝑨subscript𝑅𝑘superscriptℝsubscript𝑀𝑘𝑁{\boldsymbol{A}}_{R_{k}}\in\mathbb{R}^{M_{k}\times N} is a projection matrix. We set the scaling factor as αk(t,b)=1/‖𝒈~k(t,b)‖superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘𝑡𝑏1normsuperscriptsubscript~𝒈𝑘𝑡𝑏\alpha_{k}^{(t,b)}={1}/{\|\tilde{\boldsymbol{g}}_{k}^{(t,b)}\|} and the projection matrix as an IID Gaussian random matrix333The design of the projection matrix can be optimized for further reducing the compression error. Other types of random matrices are also applicable in (10). with zero mean and unit variance, i.e., (𝑨Rk)m,n∼𝒩​(0,1)similar-tosubscriptsubscript𝑨subscript𝑅𝑘𝑚𝑛𝒩01({\boldsymbol{A}}_{R_{k}})_{m,n}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,1), ∀m,nfor-all𝑚𝑛\forall m,n. Under these settings, the design of vector quantizer as well as the optimization of Sksubscript𝑆𝑘S_{k} and Rksubscript𝑅𝑘R_{k} will be elucidated in Sec. IV. We assume444In practice, this assumption can be realized by sharing the same N×N𝑁𝑁N\times N random projection matrix between the PS and the devices before the beginning of the training process. Then, in each local block update compression, device k𝑘k can determine its projection matrix by selecting the first Mksubscript𝑀𝑘M_{k} rows of the shared projection matrix. that the devices with the same dimensionality reduction ratio adopt the same projection matrix. Our dimensionality reduction step is summarized in Step 4 of Procedure 2.

III-B3 Vector quantization

In the vector quantization step, each compressed local block update is quantized using a Qk​Mksubscript𝑄𝑘subscript𝑀𝑘Q_{k}M_{k}-bit vector quantizer, where Qksubscript𝑄𝑘Q_{k} is the number of quantization bits per entry chosen by device k𝑘k. To avoid the computational complexity for quantizing a high-dimensional vector, the compressed local block update 𝒙k(t,b)superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑘𝑡𝑏{\boldsymbol{x}}_{k}^{(t,b)} is first partitioned into Pksubscript𝑃𝑘P_{k} subvectors of dimension L=MkPk𝐿subscript𝑀𝑘subscript𝑃𝑘L=\frac{M_{k}}{P_{k}}, i.e., 𝒙k(t,b)=[(𝒗k,1(t,b))𝖳,…,(𝒗k,Pk(t,b))𝖳]𝖳superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑘𝑡𝑏superscriptsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝒗𝑘1𝑡𝑏𝖳…superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝒗𝑘subscript𝑃𝑘𝑡𝑏𝖳𝖳{{\boldsymbol{x}}}_{k}^{(t,b)}=\big{[}({\boldsymbol{v}}_{k,1}^{(t,b)})^{\sf T},\ldots,({\boldsymbol{v}}_{k,P_{k}}^{(t,b)})^{\sf T}\big{]}^{\sf T}, as in [15]. Then, these subvectors are quantized in parallel using a Qk​Lsubscript𝑄𝑘𝐿Q_{k}L-bit vector quantizer. The resulting quantized subvector is given by

𝒗^k,p(t,b)=𝖰𝒞​(𝒗k,p(t,b)),p∈{1,…,Pk},formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript^𝒗𝑘𝑝𝑡𝑏subscript𝖰𝒞superscriptsubscript𝒗𝑘𝑝𝑡𝑏𝑝1…subscript𝑃𝑘\displaystyle\hat{\boldsymbol{v}}_{k,p}^{(t,b)}={\sf Q}_{\mathcal{C}}({\boldsymbol{v}}_{k,p}^{(t,b)}),~{}p\in\{1,\ldots,P_{k}\}, (11)

where 𝖰𝒞:ℝL→𝒞:subscript𝖰𝒞→superscriptℝ𝐿𝒞{\sf Q}_{\mathcal{C}}:\mathbb{R}^{L}\rightarrow\mathcal{C} is a vector quantizer with a codebook 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} such that |𝒞|≤2Qk​L𝒞superscript2subscript𝑄𝑘𝐿|\mathcal{C}|\leq 2^{Q_{k}L}. The optimal design of the vector quantizer will be discussed in Sec. IV-A. Our vector quantization step is summarized in Steps 5–6 of Procedure 2. After vector quantization, the quantized subvectors {𝒗^k,p(t,b)}p=1Pksuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript^𝒗𝑘𝑝𝑡𝑏𝑝1subscript𝑃𝑘\{\hat{\boldsymbol{v}}_{k,p}^{(t,b)}\}_{p=1}^{P_{k}} and the scaling factor αk(t,b)superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘𝑡𝑏\alpha_{k}^{(t,b)} are encoded into digital bits, denoted by Ωk,b(t)superscriptsubscriptΩ𝑘𝑏𝑡\Omega_{k,b}^{(t)}, for digital communications.

III-C Reconstruction of Global Block Update

The global block reconstruction process of FedVQCS consists of two steps: (i) group-wise aggregation, and (ii) sparse signal recovery, as summarized in Procedure 3. The details of each step performed by the PS for block b𝑏b in round t𝑡t are elaborated below.

III-C1 Group-wise aggregation

In the group-wise aggregation step, the PS groups the compressed local block updates with the same dimension and, then, aggregates only the compressed updates in the same group. Meanwhile, to facilitate an accurate reconstruction of the aggregated block update, the PS limits the number of the compressed updates in each group to be less than or equal to K′superscript𝐾′K^{\prime}. By adjusting K′superscript𝐾′K^{\prime}, the PS can control the tradeoff between the complexity and accuracy of the global block reconstruction, as will be justified later.

Let 𝒦gsubscript𝒦𝑔\mathcal{K}_{g} be the indices of the compressed local block updates in group g∈{1,…,G}𝑔1…𝐺g\in\{1,\ldots,G\}, where G𝐺G is the number of groups, and 𝒦1,…,𝒦Gsubscript𝒦1…subscript𝒦𝐺\mathcal{K}_{1},\ldots,\mathcal{K}_{G} are mutually exclusive subsets of 𝒦𝒦\mathcal{K} such that 𝒦=⋃g=1G𝒦g𝒦superscriptsubscript𝑔1𝐺subscript𝒦𝑔\mathcal{K}=\bigcup_{g=1}^{G}\mathcal{K}_{g}. For ease of exposition, we assume that |𝒦g|=K′subscript𝒦𝑔superscript𝐾′|\mathcal{K}_{g}|=K^{\prime}, ∀gfor-all𝑔\forall g. Under error-free reception of the transmitted data {Ωk(t,b)}k∈𝒦subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptΩ𝑘𝑡𝑏𝑘𝒦\{\Omega_{k}^{(t,b)}\}_{k\in\mathcal{K}}, the PS obtains the quantized subvectors {𝒗^k,p(t,b)}p=1Pksuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript^𝒗𝑘𝑝𝑡𝑏𝑝1subscript𝑃𝑘\{\hat{\boldsymbol{v}}_{k,p}^{(t,b)}\}_{p=1}^{P_{k}} and the scaling factor αk(t,b)superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘𝑡𝑏\alpha_{k}^{(t,b)} by decoding Ωk(t,b)superscriptsubscriptΩ𝑘𝑡𝑏\Omega_{k}^{(t,b)}. Let 𝒅k,p(t,b)≜𝒗^k,p(t,b)−𝒗k,p(t,b)≜superscriptsubscript𝒅𝑘𝑝𝑡𝑏superscriptsubscript^𝒗𝑘𝑝𝑡𝑏superscriptsubscript𝒗𝑘𝑝𝑡𝑏{\boldsymbol{d}}_{k,p}^{(t,b)}\triangleq\hat{\boldsymbol{v}}_{k,p}^{(t,b)}-{\boldsymbol{v}}_{k,p}^{(t,b)} be a quantization error vector. Then, from 𝒗^k,p(t,b)=𝒗k,p(t,b)+𝒅k,p(t,b)superscriptsubscript^𝒗𝑘𝑝𝑡𝑏superscriptsubscript𝒗𝑘𝑝𝑡𝑏superscriptsubscript𝒅𝑘𝑝𝑡𝑏\hat{\boldsymbol{v}}_{k,p}^{(t,b)}={\boldsymbol{v}}_{k,p}^{(t,b)}+{\boldsymbol{d}}_{k,p}^{(t,b)}, the compressed local block update 𝒙^k(t,b)superscriptsubscript^𝒙𝑘𝑡𝑏\hat{\boldsymbol{x}}_{k}^{(t,b)} is expressed as

𝒙^k(t,b)superscriptsubscript^𝒙𝑘𝑡𝑏\displaystyle\hat{\boldsymbol{x}}_{k}^{(t,b)} =[(𝒗^k,1(t,b))𝖳,…,(𝒗^k,P(t,b))𝖳]𝖳=𝒙k(t,b)+𝒅k(t,b)absentsuperscriptsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscript^𝒗𝑘1𝑡𝑏𝖳…superscriptsuperscriptsubscript^𝒗𝑘𝑃𝑡𝑏𝖳𝖳superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑘𝑡𝑏superscriptsubscript𝒅𝑘𝑡𝑏\displaystyle=\big{[}(\hat{\boldsymbol{v}}_{k,1}^{(t,b)})^{\sf T},\ldots,(\hat{\boldsymbol{v}}_{k,P}^{(t,b)})^{\sf T}\big{]}^{\sf T}={\boldsymbol{x}}_{k}^{(t,b)}+{\boldsymbol{d}}_{k}^{(t,b)}
=αk(t,b)​𝑨Rk​𝒈~k(t,b)+𝒅k(t,b),absentsuperscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘𝑡𝑏subscript𝑨subscript𝑅𝑘superscriptsubscript~𝒈𝑘𝑡𝑏superscriptsubscript𝒅𝑘𝑡𝑏\displaystyle=\alpha_{k}^{(t,b)}{\boldsymbol{A}}_{R_{k}}\tilde{\boldsymbol{g}}_{k}^{(t,b)}+{\boldsymbol{d}}_{k}^{(t,b)}, (12)

where 𝒅k(t,b)=[(𝒅k,1(t,b))𝖳,…,(𝒅k,P(t,b))𝖳]𝖳superscriptsubscript𝒅𝑘𝑡𝑏superscriptsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝒅𝑘1𝑡𝑏𝖳…superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝒅𝑘𝑃𝑡𝑏𝖳𝖳{\boldsymbol{d}}_{k}^{(t,b)}=\big{[}({\boldsymbol{d}}_{k,1}^{(t,b)})^{\sf T},\ldots,({\boldsymbol{d}}_{k,P}^{(t,b)})^{\sf T}\big{]}^{\sf T}. Because Rk=Rgsubscript𝑅𝑘subscript𝑅𝑔R_{k}=R_{g}, ∀k∈𝒦gfor-all𝑘subscript𝒦𝑔\forall k\in\mathcal{K}_{g}, the PS can aggregate the compressed local block updates in group g𝑔g as

𝒚𝒦g(t,b)=∑k∈𝒦gρkαk(t,b)​𝒙^k(t,b)=𝑨Rg​𝒈~𝒦g(t,b)+𝒅𝒦g(t,b),superscriptsubscript𝒚subscript𝒦𝑔𝑡𝑏subscript𝑘subscript𝒦𝑔subscript𝜌𝑘superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘𝑡𝑏superscriptsubscript^𝒙𝑘𝑡𝑏subscript𝑨subscript𝑅𝑔superscriptsubscript~𝒈subscript𝒦𝑔𝑡𝑏superscriptsubscript𝒅subscript𝒦𝑔𝑡𝑏\displaystyle{\boldsymbol{y}}_{\mathcal{K}_{g}}^{(t,b)}=\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}_{g}}\frac{\rho_{k}}{\alpha_{k}^{(t,b)}}\hat{\boldsymbol{x}}_{k}^{(t,b)}={\boldsymbol{A}}_{R_{g}}\tilde{\boldsymbol{g}}_{\mathcal{K}_{g}}^{(t,b)}+{\boldsymbol{d}}_{\mathcal{K}_{g}}^{(t,b)}, (13)

where 𝒈~𝒦g(t,b)=∑k∈𝒦gρk​𝒈~k(t,b)superscriptsubscript~𝒈subscript𝒦𝑔𝑡𝑏subscript𝑘subscript𝒦𝑔subscript𝜌𝑘superscriptsubscript~𝒈𝑘𝑡𝑏\tilde{\boldsymbol{g}}_{\mathcal{K}_{g}}^{(t,b)}=\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}_{g}}\rho_{k}\tilde{\boldsymbol{g}}_{k}^{(t,b)} is the aggregated block update of group g𝑔g for block b𝑏b in round t𝑡t and 𝒅𝒦g(t,b)=∑k∈𝒦g(ρk/αk(t,b))​𝒅k(t,b)superscriptsubscript𝒅subscript𝒦𝑔𝑡𝑏subscript𝑘subscript𝒦𝑔subscript𝜌𝑘superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘𝑡𝑏superscriptsubscript𝒅𝑘𝑡𝑏{\boldsymbol{d}}_{\mathcal{K}_{g}}^{(t,b)}=\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}_{g}}({\rho_{k}}/{\alpha_{k}^{(t,b)}}){\boldsymbol{d}}_{k}^{(t,b)}.

III-C2 Sparse signal recovery

In the sparse signal recovery step, the PS estimates the aggregated block update 𝒈~𝒦g(t,b)superscriptsubscript~𝒈subscript𝒦𝑔𝑡𝑏\tilde{\boldsymbol{g}}_{\mathcal{K}_{g}}^{(t,b)} from its noisy linear observation 𝒚𝒦g(t,b)superscriptsubscript𝒚subscript𝒦𝑔𝑡𝑏{\boldsymbol{y}}_{\mathcal{K}_{g}}^{(t,b)} in (13) for every group g𝑔g. As can be seen in (13), the estimation of 𝒈~𝒦g(t,b)superscriptsubscript~𝒈subscript𝒦𝑔𝑡𝑏\tilde{\boldsymbol{g}}_{\mathcal{K}_{g}}^{(t,b)} from 𝒚𝒦g(t,b)superscriptsubscript𝒚subscript𝒦𝑔𝑡𝑏{\boldsymbol{y}}_{\mathcal{K}_{g}}^{(t,b)} is a well-known sparse signal recovery problem [34]. Motivated by this fact, the PS employs a sparse signal recovery algorithm (e.g., [35, 36]) to estimate 𝒈~𝒦g(t,b)superscriptsubscript~𝒈subscript𝒦𝑔𝑡𝑏\tilde{\boldsymbol{g}}_{\mathcal{K}_{g}}^{(t,b)} from 𝒚𝒦g(t,b)superscriptsubscript𝒚subscript𝒦𝑔𝑡𝑏{\boldsymbol{y}}_{\mathcal{K}_{g}}^{(t,b)} for every group g𝑔g. The sparse signal recovery algorithm considered in our work will be elucidated in Sec. V. If the sparsity level of 𝒈~𝒦g(t,b)superscriptsubscript~𝒈subscript𝒦𝑔𝑡𝑏\tilde{\boldsymbol{g}}_{\mathcal{K}_{g}}^{(t,b)} is sufficiently smaller than the dimension of 𝒚𝒦g(t,b)superscriptsubscript𝒚subscript𝒦𝑔𝑡𝑏{\boldsymbol{y}}_{\mathcal{K}_{g}}^{(t,b)}, which will be justified in Sec. IV-B, the PS is able to attain an accurate estimate of 𝒈~𝒦g(t,b)superscriptsubscript~𝒈subscript𝒦𝑔𝑡𝑏\tilde{\boldsymbol{g}}_{\mathcal{K}_{g}}^{(t,b)}. After the recovery of the aggregated block updates for all groups, the PS reconstructs the global block update as 𝒈^𝒦(t,b)=∑g=1G𝒈^𝒦g(t,b)superscriptsubscript^𝒈𝒦𝑡𝑏superscriptsubscript𝑔1𝐺superscriptsubscript^𝒈subscript𝒦𝑔𝑡𝑏\hat{\boldsymbol{g}}_{\mathcal{K}}^{(t,b)}=\sum_{g=1}^{G}\hat{\boldsymbol{g}}_{\mathcal{K}_{g}}^{(t,b)}. Finally, the PS obtains the global model update 𝒈^𝒦(t)superscriptsubscript^𝒈𝒦𝑡\hat{\boldsymbol{g}}_{\mathcal{K}}^{(t)} by concatenating all the global block updates {𝒈^𝒦(t,b)}b=1Bsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript^𝒈𝒦𝑡𝑏𝑏1𝐵\{\hat{\boldsymbol{g}}_{\mathcal{K}}^{(t,b)}\}_{b=1}^{B} (see Step 14 of Procedure 1).

Remark 1 (Communication overhead of FedVQCS): In FedVQCS, each device k𝑘k transmits the digital bits representing the quantized subvectors {𝒗^k,p(t,b)}p=1Pksuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript^𝒗𝑘𝑝𝑡𝑏𝑝1subscript𝑃𝑘\{\hat{\boldsymbol{v}}_{k,p}^{(t,b)}\}_{p=1}^{P_{k}} and the scaling factor αk(t,b)superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘𝑡𝑏\alpha_{k}^{(t,b)} for every block b∈{1,…,B}𝑏1…𝐵b\in\{1,\ldots,B\} in round t𝑡t. Because every quantized subvector is represented by Qk​Lsubscript𝑄𝑘𝐿Q_{k}L bits, the total number of digital bits required for transmitting the local model update at each device is given by (Qk​L​Pk+32)​B=(Qk​Mk+32)​Bsubscript𝑄𝑘𝐿subscript𝑃𝑘32𝐵subscript𝑄𝑘subscript𝑀𝑘32𝐵(Q_{k}LP_{k}+32)B=(Q_{k}M_{k}+32)B for every round. If Qk​Mk≫32much-greater-thansubscript𝑄𝑘subscript𝑀𝑘32Q_{k}M_{k}\gg 32, the communication overhead for device k𝑘k is Qk​Mk​BN​B=QkRksubscript𝑄𝑘subscript𝑀𝑘𝐵𝑁𝐵subscript𝑄𝑘subscript𝑅𝑘\frac{Q_{k}M_{k}B}{NB}=\frac{Q_{k}}{R_{k}} bits per local model entry. Owing to this feature, FedVQCS allows each device to not only reduce the communication overhead for transmitting its local model update but also control this overhead by adjusting the values of Qksubscript𝑄𝑘Q_{k} and Rksubscript𝑅𝑘R_{k} based on the capacity of the wireless link. Therefore, FedVQCS is a powerful framework for enabling wireless FL with limited link capacity. The optimization of Qksubscript𝑄𝑘Q_{k} and Rksubscript𝑅𝑘R_{k} for a given link capacity will be elucidated in Sec. IV-B. It should also be noted that in FedVQCS, the PS and devices need to share some information such as 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}, 𝑨Rksubscript𝑨subscript𝑅𝑘{\boldsymbol{A}}_{R_{k}}, and B𝐵B before the beginning of training process. Fortunately, the communication overhead required for sharing this information is marginal compared to that required for transmitting local model updates during the training process. Hence, in this work, we consider only the significant communication overhead that occurs during the local model update transmission in FL.

Remark 2 (Comparison with existing FL frameworks): The existing FL frameworks in [13, 14, 15] consider vector quantization for compressing the local model updates, but without applying any dimensionality reduction technique. Unlike these frameworks, FedVQCS applies the CS-based dimensionality reduction before the vector quantization, which reduces the dimension of the local model update by allowing the transmission of its most significant entries only. In [19, 20, 21, 22, 23], it has been reported that the accuracy of FL does not severely degrade when sending a sufficient number of the significant entries. Therefore, FedVQCS achieves further compression of the local model updates compared with the frameworks in [13, 14, 15], without significantly sacrificing the learning accuracy. The existing FL frameworks in [16, 17, 18] employ CS-based dimensionality reduction but rely solely on scalar quantization. In contrast, FedVQCS empolys vector quantization, which generally outperforms scalar quantization in terms of quantization error. Furthermore, FedVQCS optimizes key parameters such as the number of quantization bits per entry Q𝑄Q, a sparsity level S𝑆S, and a dimensionality reduction ratio R𝑅R to minimize the reconstruction error at the PS (see Sec. IV-B). This optimization approach has not been thoroughly explored in the FL literature. Therefore, FedVQCS enables a more accurate reconstruction of the global model update compared to the QCS-based FL frameworks in [16, 17, 18].

IV Optimization and Convergence Analysis of FedVQCS

Here, we first optimize the design of a vector quantizer for the local block compression process of FedVQCS and then optimize the key design parameters of this compression process for minimizing the reconstruction error of the global model update at the PS. We also characterize the convergence rate of FedVQCS, while considering the reconstruction error at the PS.

IV-A Optimal Design of Vector Quantizer

In FedVQCS, a proper design of the vector quantizer in (11) is critical for reducing the reconstruction error of the global model update at the PS. The underlying challenge of the vector quantizer design is that the exact distribution of the quantizer input depends on many factors such as the global model choice, the local training data distribution, and the loss function type. Moreover, the optimal vector quantizer may differ across partitions, blocks, devices, and communication rounds, which can lead to additional communication overhead for transmitting the information of the quantizer between the PS and the devices.

Fortunately, the above challenges can be readily addressed in FedVQCS. First of all, it is reported in [18] that a sparsified local block update 𝒈~k(t,b)superscriptsubscript~𝒈𝑘𝑡𝑏\tilde{\boldsymbol{g}}_{k}^{(t,b)} can be modeled as an IID random vector whose entry follows a Bernoulli Gaussian-mixture distribution. Hence, for a large N𝑁N, the projected local model update 𝒙k(t,b)=αk(t,b)​𝑨Rk​𝒈~k(t,b)superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑘𝑡𝑏superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘𝑡𝑏subscript𝑨subscript𝑅𝑘superscriptsubscript~𝒈𝑘𝑡𝑏{\boldsymbol{x}}_{k}^{(t,b)}=\alpha_{k}^{(t,b)}{\boldsymbol{A}}_{R_{k}}\tilde{\boldsymbol{g}}_{k}^{(t,b)} can be modeled as an Mksubscript𝑀𝑘M_{k}-dimensional IID Gaussian random vector with zero mean and unit variance by the central limit theorem, provided that 𝑨Rksubscript𝑨subscript𝑅𝑘{\boldsymbol{A}}_{R_{k}} is an IID Gaussian random matrix with αk(t,b)=1/‖𝒈~k(t,b)‖superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘𝑡𝑏1normsuperscriptsubscript~𝒈𝑘𝑡𝑏\alpha_{k}^{(t,b)}={1}/{\|\tilde{\boldsymbol{g}}_{k}^{(t,b)}\|}. This implies that every subvector of 𝒙k(t,b)superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑘𝑡𝑏{\boldsymbol{x}}_{k}^{(t,b)} can also be modeled as an L𝐿L-dimensional IID Gaussian random vector whose distribution is same for all partitions, blocks, devices, and communication rounds, i.e., 𝒗k,p(t,b)∼𝒩​(𝟎L,𝑰L)similar-tosuperscriptsubscript𝒗𝑘𝑝𝑡𝑏𝒩subscript0𝐿subscript𝑰𝐿{\boldsymbol{v}}_{k,p}^{(t,b)}\sim\mathcal{N}({\boldsymbol{0}}_{L},{\boldsymbol{I}}_{L}), ∀k,p,t,bfor-all𝑘𝑝𝑡𝑏\forall k,p,t,b. Motivated by this observation, in FedVQCS, we use the vector quantizer optimized for the distribution of 𝒗∼𝒩​(𝟎L,𝑰L)similar-to𝒗𝒩subscript0𝐿subscript𝑰𝐿{\boldsymbol{v}}\sim\mathcal{N}({\boldsymbol{0}}_{L},{\boldsymbol{I}}_{L}) for a given number of quantization bits. Owing to this feature, both the PS and devices in FedVQCS can utilize the same optimal quantizer by sharing the number of quantization bits.

IV-A1 Quantizer design problem

To determine the optimal vector quantizer for the distribution of 𝒗∼𝒩​(𝟎L,𝑰L)similar-to𝒗𝒩subscript0𝐿subscript𝑰𝐿{\boldsymbol{v}}\sim\mathcal{N}({\boldsymbol{0}}_{L},{\boldsymbol{I}}_{L}), we consider a shape-gain quantizer, which is effective in quantizing an IID Gaussian random vector while enabling the efficient construction of the optimal codebook [25]. When employing this quantizer, the shape of 𝒗𝒗{\boldsymbol{v}}, defined as 𝒔=𝒗/‖𝒗‖𝒔𝒗norm𝒗{\boldsymbol{s}}={\boldsymbol{v}}/\|{\boldsymbol{v}}\|, and its gain defined as h=‖𝒗‖ℎnorm𝒗h=\|{\boldsymbol{v}}\| are independently quantized. Let 𝖰𝒞s​(𝒔)=arg⁡min𝒔^∈𝒞s​‖𝒔−𝒔^‖2subscript𝖰subscript𝒞s𝒔^𝒔subscript𝒞ssuperscriptnorm𝒔^𝒔2{\sf Q}_{\mathcal{C}_{\rm s}}({\boldsymbol{s}})=\underset{\hat{\boldsymbol{s}}\in\mathcal{C}_{\rm s}}{\arg\!\min}~{}\|{\boldsymbol{s}}-\hat{\boldsymbol{s}}\|^{2} and 𝖰𝒞h​(h)=arg⁡minh^∈𝒞h​|h−h^|2subscript𝖰subscript𝒞hℎ^ℎsubscript𝒞hsuperscriptℎ^ℎ2{\sf Q}_{\mathcal{C}_{\rm h}}(h)=\underset{\hat{h}\in\mathcal{C}_{\rm h}}{\arg\!\min}~{}|h-\hat{h}|^{2} be the shape and gain quantizers using the minimum Euclidean distance criterion, respectively. Then, the output of the shape-gain quantizer will be 𝒗^=h^​𝒔^^𝒗^ℎ^𝒔\hat{\boldsymbol{v}}=\hat{h}\hat{\boldsymbol{s}}, where 𝒔^=𝖰𝒞s​(𝒔)^𝒔subscript𝖰subscript𝒞s𝒔\hat{\boldsymbol{s}}={\sf Q}_{\mathcal{C}_{\rm s}}({\boldsymbol{s}}) and h^=𝖰𝒞h​(h)^ℎsubscript𝖰subscript𝒞hℎ\hat{h}={\sf Q}_{\mathcal{C}_{\rm h}}(h). As such, the MSE of the shape-gain quantizer can be approximated by [25]

𝔼​[‖𝒗−h^​𝒔^‖2]𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm𝒗^ℎ^𝒔2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\big{[}\|{\boldsymbol{v}}-\hat{h}\hat{\boldsymbol{s}}\|^{2}\big{]} ≈L​𝔼​[‖𝒔−𝒔^‖2]+𝔼​[|h−h^|2]absent𝐿𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm𝒔^𝒔2𝔼delimited-[]superscriptℎ^ℎ2\displaystyle\approx L\mathbb{E}\big{[}\|{\boldsymbol{s}}-\hat{\boldsymbol{s}}\|^{2}\big{]}+\mathbb{E}\big{[}|{h}-\hat{h}|^{2}\big{]}
=L⋅𝖬𝖲𝖤​(𝒔;𝒞s)+𝖬𝖲𝖤​(h;𝒞h),absent⋅𝐿𝖬𝖲𝖤𝒔subscript𝒞s𝖬𝖲𝖤ℎsubscript𝒞h\displaystyle=L\cdot{\sf MSE}({\boldsymbol{s}};\mathcal{C}_{\rm s})+{\sf MSE}(h;\mathcal{C}_{\rm h}), (14)

where 𝖬𝖲𝖤​(h;𝒞h)=𝔼​[|h−𝖰𝒞h​(h)|2]𝖬𝖲𝖤ℎsubscript𝒞h𝔼delimited-[]superscriptℎsubscript𝖰subscript𝒞hℎ2{\sf MSE}(h;\mathcal{C}_{\rm h})=\mathbb{E}\big{[}|h-{\sf Q}_{\mathcal{C}_{\rm h}}(h)|^{2}\big{]} and 𝖬𝖲𝖤​(𝒔;𝒞s)=𝔼​[‖𝒔−𝖰𝒞s​(𝒔)‖2]𝖬𝖲𝖤𝒔subscript𝒞s𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm𝒔subscript𝖰subscript𝒞s𝒔2{\sf MSE}({\boldsymbol{s}};\mathcal{C}_{\rm s})=\mathbb{E}\big{[}\|{\boldsymbol{s}}-{\sf Q}_{\mathcal{C}_{\rm s}}({\boldsymbol{s}})\|^{2}\big{]}. By utilizing this approximation, we formulate the shape-gain quantizer design problem for a given number of quantization bits Q​L𝑄𝐿QL as follows:

arg⁡min𝒞s,𝒞h​L⋅𝖬𝖲𝖤​(𝒗/‖𝒗‖;𝒞s)+𝖬𝖲𝖤​(‖𝒗‖;𝒞h),⋅subscript𝒞ssubscript𝒞h𝐿𝖬𝖲𝖤𝒗norm𝒗subscript𝒞s𝖬𝖲𝖤norm𝒗subscript𝒞h\displaystyle\underset{{\mathcal{C}_{\rm s}},{\mathcal{C}_{\rm h}}}{\arg\!\min}~{}L\cdot{\sf MSE}({\boldsymbol{v}}/\|{\boldsymbol{v}}\|;\mathcal{C}_{\rm s})+{\sf MSE}(\|{\boldsymbol{v}}\|;\mathcal{C}_{\rm h}),
 s.t. ​𝒗∼𝒩​(𝟎L,𝑰L),|𝒞s|≤2Qs,|𝒞h|≤2Qh,formulae-sequencesimilar-to s.t. 𝒗𝒩subscript0𝐿subscript𝑰𝐿formulae-sequencesubscript𝒞ssuperscript2subscript𝑄ssubscript𝒞hsuperscript2subscript𝑄h\displaystyle\text{~{}~{}~{}s.t.~{}~{}~{}}{\boldsymbol{v}}\sim\mathcal{N}({\boldsymbol{0}}_{L},{\boldsymbol{I}}_{L}),~{}|\mathcal{C}_{\rm s}|\leq 2^{Q_{\rm s}},~{}|\mathcal{C}_{\rm h}|\leq 2^{Q_{\rm h}},
Qs+Qh≤Q​L.subscript𝑄ssubscript𝑄h𝑄𝐿\displaystyle~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}~{}\,~{}Q_{\rm s}+Q_{\rm h}\leq QL. (15)

This problem is solved using the following strategy: First, we separately determine the MSE-optimal shape and gain quantizers for a fixed bit allocation (Qs,Qh)subscript𝑄ssubscript𝑄h(Q_{\rm s},Q_{\rm h}) and, then, we derive the optimal bit allocation (Qs⋆,Qh⋆)superscriptsubscript𝑄s⋆superscriptsubscript𝑄h⋆(Q_{\rm s}^{\star},Q_{\rm h}^{\star}) for the optimal shape and gain quantizers.

IV-A2 Design of shape quantizer

When the number of shape quantization bits is given by Qssubscript𝑄sQ_{\rm s}, the MSE-optimal shape quantizer is obtained by solving the following problem:

𝒞s⋆=arg⁡min|𝒞s|≤2Qs​𝖬𝖲𝖤​(𝒔;𝒞s),superscriptsubscript𝒞s⋆subscript𝒞ssuperscript2subscript𝑄s𝖬𝖲𝖤𝒔subscript𝒞s\displaystyle\mathcal{C}_{\rm s}^{\star}=\underset{|\mathcal{C}_{\rm s}|\leq 2^{Q_{\rm s}}}{\arg\!\min}~{}{\sf MSE}({\boldsymbol{s}};\mathcal{C}_{\rm s}), (16)

where 𝒔=𝒗/‖𝒗‖𝒔𝒗norm𝒗{\boldsymbol{s}}={\boldsymbol{v}}/\|{\boldsymbol{v}}\| with 𝒗∼𝒩​(𝟎L,𝑰L)similar-to𝒗𝒩subscript0𝐿subscript𝑰𝐿{\boldsymbol{v}}\sim\mathcal{N}({\boldsymbol{0}}_{L},{\boldsymbol{I}}_{L}). Unfortunately, it is hard to characterize the exact solution of this problem; thus, as an alternative, we consider an approximate solution by replacing the Euclidean distance with the squared chordal distance, as in [15]. Then the approximate solution of (16) is obtained as an even Grassmannian codebook 𝒞s⋆superscriptsubscript𝒞s⋆\mathcal{C}_{\rm s}^{\star} that can be constructed as follows [15]:

  • •

    Solve the Grassmannian line packing problem formulated as [27]:

    max𝒞s+⁡min𝒔^≠𝒔^′,𝒔^,𝒔^′∈𝒞s+⁡d​(𝒔^,𝒔^′),s.t.​|𝒞s+|=2Qs−1,subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝒞ssubscriptformulae-sequence^𝒔superscript^𝒔′^𝒔superscript^𝒔′superscriptsubscript𝒞s𝑑^𝒔superscript^𝒔′s.t.superscriptsubscript𝒞ssuperscript2subscript𝑄s1\displaystyle\max_{\mathcal{C}_{\rm s}^{+}}\min_{\hat{\boldsymbol{s}}\neq\hat{\boldsymbol{s}}^{\prime},\hat{\boldsymbol{s}},\hat{\boldsymbol{s}}^{\prime}\in\mathcal{C}_{\rm s}^{+}}d(\hat{\boldsymbol{s}},\hat{\boldsymbol{s}}^{\prime}),~{}~{}\text{s.t.}~{}~{}|\mathcal{C}_{\rm s}^{+}|=2^{Q_{\rm s}-1}, (17)

    where d​(𝒔^,𝒔^′)=1−|𝒔^𝖳​𝒔^′|2𝑑^𝒔superscript^𝒔′1superscriptsuperscript^𝒔𝖳superscript^𝒔′2d(\hat{\boldsymbol{s}},\hat{\boldsymbol{s}}^{\prime})=\sqrt{1-|\hat{\boldsymbol{s}}^{\sf T}\hat{\boldsymbol{s}}^{\prime}|^{2}}.

  • •

    Construct the even Grassmannian codebook as 𝒞s⋆=𝒞s+​⋃𝒞s−superscriptsubscript𝒞s⋆superscriptsubscript𝒞ssuperscriptsubscript𝒞s\mathcal{C}_{\rm s}^{\star}=\mathcal{C}_{\rm s}^{+}\bigcup\mathcal{C}_{\rm s}^{-} where 𝒞s−={𝒔:−𝒔∈𝒞s+}superscriptsubscript𝒞sconditional-set𝒔𝒔superscriptsubscript𝒞s\mathcal{C}_{\rm s}^{-}=\{{\boldsymbol{s}}:-{\boldsymbol{s}}\in\mathcal{C}_{\rm s}^{+}\}.

We determine the optimal shape quantizer by using the even Grassmannian codebook 𝒞s⋆superscriptsubscript𝒞s⋆\mathcal{C}_{\rm s}^{\star} constructed above. The MSE of the above shape quantizer is characterized, as given in the following lemma:

Lemma 1:

For large L𝐿L, the MSE of the even Grassmannian codebook 𝒞s⋆superscriptsubscript𝒞s⋆\mathcal{C}_{\rm s}^{\star} with size 2Qssuperscript2subscript𝑄s2^{Q_{\rm s}} is bounded as

2−2​1−L−1L+1​2−2​(Qs−1)L−1≤𝖬𝖲𝖤​(𝒔;𝒞s⋆)≤2−2​(Qs−1)L−1+1.221𝐿1𝐿1superscript22subscript𝑄s1𝐿1𝖬𝖲𝖤𝒔superscriptsubscript𝒞s⋆superscript22subscript𝑄s1𝐿11\displaystyle 2-2\sqrt{1-\frac{L-1}{L+1}2^{-\frac{2(Q_{\rm s}-1)}{L-1}}}\leq{\sf MSE}({\boldsymbol{s}};\mathcal{C}_{\rm s}^{\star})\leq 2^{-\frac{2(Q_{\rm s}-1)}{L-1}+1}. (18)
Proof:

See Appendix A. ∎

IV-A3 Design of gain quantizer

When the number of gain quantization bits is given by Qhsubscript𝑄hQ_{\rm h}, the MSE-optimal gain quantizer is obtained by solving the following problem:

𝒞h⋆=arg⁡min|𝒞h|≤2Qh​𝖬𝖲𝖤​(h;𝒞h),superscriptsubscript𝒞h⋆subscript𝒞hsuperscript2subscript𝑄h𝖬𝖲𝖤ℎsubscript𝒞h\displaystyle\mathcal{C}_{\rm h}^{\star}=\underset{|\mathcal{C}_{\rm h}|\leq 2^{Q_{\rm h}}}{\arg\!\min}~{}{\sf MSE}(h;\mathcal{C}_{\rm h}), (19)

where h=‖𝒗‖ℎnorm𝒗h=\|{\boldsymbol{v}}\|. From 𝒗∼𝒩​(𝟎L,𝑰L)similar-to𝒗𝒩subscript0𝐿subscript𝑰𝐿{\boldsymbol{v}}\sim\mathcal{N}({\boldsymbol{0}}_{L},{\boldsymbol{I}}_{L}), the probability density function of the gain h=‖𝒗‖ℎnorm𝒗h=\|{\boldsymbol{v}}\| is given by

fh​(z)=2​zL−1​exp⁡(−z22)Γ​(L/2)​2L/2,subscript𝑓ℎ𝑧2superscript𝑧𝐿1superscript𝑧22Γ𝐿2superscript2𝐿2\displaystyle f_{h}(z)=\frac{2z^{L-1}\exp{(\frac{-z^{2}}{2})}}{\Gamma(L/2)2^{L/2}}, (20)

where Γ​(r)=∫0∞tr−1​e−t​dtΓ𝑟superscriptsubscript0superscript𝑡𝑟1superscript𝑒𝑡differential-d𝑡\Gamma(r)=\int_{0}^{\infty}t^{r-1}e^{-t}{\rm d}t. Because this distribution is strictly log-concave, the Lloyd–Max algorithm in [26] converges to a globally optimal quantizer in terms of minimizing the MSE [37]. Hence, when Qh>0subscript𝑄h0Q_{\rm h}>0, we determine the optimal gain quantizerby applying the Lloyd–Max algorithm for the distribution in (20). When Qh=0subscript𝑄h0Q_{\rm h}=0, our strategy is to approximate the gain h=‖𝒗‖ℎnorm𝒗h=\|{\boldsymbol{v}}\| as its expected value 𝔼​[h]=2​Γ​((L+1)/2)Γ​(L/2)𝔼delimited-[]ℎ2Γ𝐿12Γ𝐿2\mathbb{E}[h]=\sqrt{2}\frac{\Gamma\left((L+1)/2\right)}{\Gamma\left(L/2\right)} based on its distribution. Considering these two cases, the MSE of the above gain quantizer is characterized, as given in the following lemma:

Lemma 2:

The MSE of the optimal gain quantizer is approximated by

𝖬𝖲𝖤​(h;𝒞h⋆)≈{χL​2−2​(Qh+1),Qh>0,L−2​πβ2​(L2,12),Qh=0,𝖬𝖲𝖤ℎsuperscriptsubscript𝒞h⋆casessubscript𝜒𝐿superscript22subscript𝑄h1subscript𝑄h0𝐿2𝜋superscript𝛽2𝐿212subscript𝑄h0\displaystyle{\sf MSE}(h;\mathcal{C}_{\rm h}^{\star})\approx\begin{cases}\chi_{L}2^{-2(Q_{\rm h}+1)},&Q_{\rm h}>0,\\ L-\frac{2\pi}{\beta^{2}\left(\frac{L}{2},\frac{1}{2}\right)},&Q_{\rm h}=0,\end{cases} (21)

where χL=3L2​Γ3​(L+26)2​Γ​(L2)subscript𝜒𝐿superscript3𝐿2superscriptΓ3𝐿262Γ𝐿2\chi_{L}=\frac{3^{\frac{L}{2}}\Gamma^{3}(\frac{L+2}{6})}{2\Gamma(\frac{L}{2})}.

Proof:

The MSE of the Lloyd–Max codebook with size Qh≫1much-greater-thansubscript𝑄h1Q_{\rm h}\gg 1, namely 𝒞h⋆superscriptsubscript𝒞h⋆\mathcal{C}_{\rm h}^{\star}, is approximated by [38]

𝖬𝖲𝖤​(h;𝒞h⋆)𝖬𝖲𝖤ℎsuperscriptsubscript𝒞h⋆\displaystyle{\sf MSE}(h;\mathcal{C}_{\rm h}^{\star}) ≈112​(∫0∞fh​(z)​dz)3​2−2​Qhabsent112superscriptsuperscriptsubscript0subscript𝑓ℎ𝑧differential-d𝑧3superscript22subscript𝑄h\displaystyle\approx\frac{1}{12}\left(\int_{0}^{\infty}f_{h}(z){\rm d}z\right)^{3}2^{-2Q_{\rm h}}
=3L2​Γ3​(L+26)8​Γ​(L2)​2−2​Qh.absentsuperscript3𝐿2superscriptΓ3𝐿268Γ𝐿2superscript22subscript𝑄h\displaystyle=\frac{3^{\frac{L}{2}}\Gamma^{3}\left(\frac{L+2}{6}\right)}{8\Gamma\left(\frac{L}{2}\right)}2^{-2Q_{\rm h}}. (22)

We use the above expression for approximating the MSE of the Lloyd–Max quantizer for Qh>0subscript𝑄h0Q_{\rm h}>0. The MSE of h^=𝔼​[h]^ℎ𝔼delimited-[]ℎ\hat{h}=\mathbb{E}[h] is computed as

𝔼​[(h−𝔼​[h])2]=𝔼​[h2]−(𝔼​[h])2=L−2​πβ2​(L2,12),𝔼delimited-[]superscriptℎ𝔼delimited-[]ℎ2𝔼delimited-[]superscriptℎ2superscript𝔼delimited-[]ℎ2𝐿2𝜋superscript𝛽2𝐿212\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[(h-\mathbb{E}[h])^{2}]=\mathbb{E}[h^{2}]-(\mathbb{E}[h])^{2}=L-\frac{2\pi}{\beta^{2}(\frac{L}{2},\frac{1}{2})}, (23)

where β​(r,s)=∫01tr−1​(1−t)s−1​dt𝛽𝑟𝑠superscriptsubscript01superscript𝑡𝑟1superscript1𝑡𝑠1differential-d𝑡\beta(r,s)=\int_{0}^{1}t^{r-1}(1-t)^{s-1}{\rm d}t. This expression gives the MSE of the optimal gain quantizer for Qh=0subscript𝑄h0Q_{\rm h}=0. ∎

IV-A4 Optimal bit allocation

Now, we derive the optimal bit allocation for the optimal shape and gain quantizers based on the MSE characterizations in (18) and (21). This result is given in the following theorem:

Theorem 1:

If both the upper bound in (18) and the approximation in (21) hold with equality, the optimal bit allocation (Qs⋆,Qh⋆)superscriptsubscript𝑄s⋆superscriptsubscript𝑄h⋆\big{(}Q_{\rm s}^{\star},Q_{\rm h}^{\star}\big{)} in (IV-A1) is given by

(Qs⋆,Qh⋆)={(Q​L−HL,Q,HL,Q),if​FL,Q≤0,(Q​L,0),if​FL,Q>0,superscriptsubscript𝑄s⋆superscriptsubscript𝑄h⋆cases𝑄𝐿subscript𝐻𝐿𝑄subscript𝐻𝐿𝑄ifsubscript𝐹𝐿𝑄0𝑄𝐿0ifsubscript𝐹𝐿𝑄0\displaystyle\big{(}Q_{\rm s}^{\star},Q_{\rm h}^{\star}\big{)}=\begin{cases}\big{(}QL-H_{L,Q},H_{L,Q}\big{)},&\text{if}~{}F_{L,Q}\leq 0,\\ \big{(}QL,0\big{)},&\text{if}~{}F_{L,Q}>0,\\ \end{cases} (24)

where HL,Q=L−12​L​log2⁡(L−12​L​χL)+Q−1subscript𝐻𝐿𝑄𝐿12𝐿subscript2𝐿12𝐿subscript𝜒𝐿𝑄1H_{L,Q}=\frac{L-1}{2L}\log_{2}\left(\frac{L-1}{2L}\chi_{L}\right)+Q-1 and

FL,Qsubscript𝐹𝐿𝑄\displaystyle F_{L,Q} =L​2−2​(Q​L−1)L−1+1​(22​HL,QL−1+1−1)absent𝐿superscript22𝑄𝐿1𝐿11superscript22subscript𝐻𝐿𝑄𝐿111\displaystyle=L2^{-\frac{2(QL-1)}{L-1}+1}\big{(}2^{\frac{2H_{L,Q}}{L-1}+1}-1\big{)}
+χL​2−2​(HL,Q+1)−L+2​πβ2​(L2,12).subscript𝜒𝐿superscript22subscript𝐻𝐿𝑄1𝐿2𝜋superscript𝛽2𝐿212\displaystyle~{}~{}~{}+\chi_{L}2^{-2(H_{L,Q}+1)}-L+\frac{2\pi}{\beta^{2}\left(\frac{L}{2},\frac{1}{2}\right)}. (25)
Proof:

From Lemma 1 and Lemma 2, the bit allocation problem with Qh>0subscript𝑄h0Q_{\rm h}>0 is

(𝐏1)subscript𝐏1\displaystyle({\bf P}_{1})~{}~{} arg⁡minQs,Qh​L​2−2​(Qs−1)L−1+1+χL​2−2​(Qh+1),subscript𝑄ssubscript𝑄h𝐿superscript22subscript𝑄s1𝐿11subscript𝜒𝐿superscript22subscript𝑄h1\displaystyle\underset{Q_{\rm s},Q_{\rm h}}{\arg\!\min}~{}L2^{-\frac{2(Q_{\rm s}-1)}{L-1}+1}+\chi_{L}2^{-2(Q_{\rm h}+1)},
 s.t. ​Qs+Qh≤Q​L,Qh>0.formulae-sequence s.t. subscript𝑄ssubscript𝑄h𝑄𝐿subscript𝑄h0\displaystyle\text{~{}~{}~{}s.t.~{}~{}~{}}Q_{\rm s}+Q_{\rm h}\leq QL,~{}Q_{\rm h}>0. (26)

Because (𝐏1)subscript𝐏1({\bf P}_{1}) is convex [15], the optimal solution is readily derived by leveraging Karush-Kuhn-Tucker (KKT) conditions:

λ⋆+∂FL,1​(Qs,Qh)∂Qs=0,λ⋆+∂FL,1​(Qs,Qh)∂Qh=0,formulae-sequencesuperscript𝜆⋆subscript𝐹𝐿1subscript𝑄ssubscript𝑄hsubscript𝑄s0superscript𝜆⋆subscript𝐹𝐿1subscript𝑄ssubscript𝑄hsubscript𝑄h0\displaystyle\lambda^{\star}+\frac{\partial F_{L,1}(Q_{\rm s},Q_{\rm h})}{\partial Q_{\rm s}}=0,~{}~{}\lambda^{\star}+\frac{\partial F_{L,1}(Q_{\rm s},Q_{\rm h})}{\partial Q_{\rm h}}=0, (27)

where FL,1​(Qs,Qh)subscript𝐹𝐿1subscript𝑄ssubscript𝑄hF_{L,1}(Q_{\rm s},Q_{\rm h}) is the objective function of (𝐏1)subscript𝐏1({\bf P}_{1}), and λ⋆superscript𝜆⋆\lambda^{\star} is a Lagrange multiplier. From the KKT conditions, the solution of (𝐏1)subscript𝐏1({\bf P}_{1}) is given by (Qs,Qh)=(Q​L−HL,Q,HL,Q)subscript𝑄ssubscript𝑄h𝑄𝐿subscript𝐻𝐿𝑄subscript𝐻𝐿𝑄\big{(}Q_{\rm s},Q_{\rm h}\big{)}=(QL-H_{L,Q},H_{L,Q}), where

HL,Q=L−12​L​log2⁡(L−12​L​χL)+Q−1.subscript𝐻𝐿𝑄𝐿12𝐿subscript2𝐿12𝐿subscript𝜒𝐿𝑄1\displaystyle H_{L,Q}=\frac{L-1}{2L}\log_{2}\left(\frac{L-1}{2L}\chi_{L}\right)+Q-1. (28)

From Lemma 1 and Lemma 2, the bit allocation problem with Qh=0subscript𝑄h0Q_{\rm h}=0 is formulated as

(𝐏2)subscript𝐏2\displaystyle({\bf P}_{2})~{}~{} arg⁡minQs≤Q​L​L​2−2​(Qs−1)L−1+1+L−2​πβ2​(L2,12).subscript𝑄s𝑄𝐿𝐿superscript22subscript𝑄s1𝐿11𝐿2𝜋superscript𝛽2𝐿212\displaystyle\underset{Q_{\rm s}\leq QL}{\arg\!\min}~{}L2^{-\frac{2(Q_{\rm s}-1)}{L-1}+1}+L-\frac{2\pi}{\beta^{2}\left(\frac{L}{2},\frac{1}{2}\right)}. (29)

Because the objective function of (𝐏2)subscript𝐏2({\bf P}_{2}) is a decreasing function of Qssubscript𝑄sQ_{\rm s}, the solution is given by Qs=Q​Lsubscript𝑄s𝑄𝐿Q_{\rm s}=QL. The optimal bit allocation in (24) can be obtained by comparing FL,1​(Q​L−HL,Q,HL,Q)subscript𝐹𝐿1𝑄𝐿subscript𝐻𝐿𝑄subscript𝐻𝐿𝑄F_{L,1}(QL-H_{L,Q},H_{L,Q}) and FL,2​(Q​L,0)subscript𝐹𝐿2𝑄𝐿0F_{L,2}({Q}L,0). This completes the proof. ∎

From Theorem 1, the MSE of the optimal shape-gain quantizer adopted in FedVQCS is approximated by

σL,Q2≈{L​2−2​(Q​L−HL,Q−1)L−1+1+χL​2−2​(HL,Q+1),FL,Q≤0,L​2−2​(Q​L−1)L−1+1+L−2​πβ2​(L2,12),FL,Q>0.superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐿𝑄2cases𝐿superscript22𝑄𝐿subscript𝐻𝐿𝑄1𝐿11subscript𝜒𝐿superscript22subscript𝐻𝐿𝑄1subscript𝐹𝐿𝑄0𝐿superscript22𝑄𝐿1𝐿11𝐿2𝜋superscript𝛽2𝐿212subscript𝐹𝐿𝑄0\displaystyle\sigma_{L,Q}^{2}\approx\begin{cases}L2^{-\frac{2(QL-H_{L,Q}-1)}{L-1}+1}+\chi_{L}2^{-2(H_{L,Q}+1)},\!\!\!\!\!&F_{L,Q}\leq 0,\\ L2^{-\frac{2(QL-1)}{L-1}+1}+L-\frac{2\pi}{\beta^{2}\left(\frac{L}{2},\frac{1}{2}\right)},&F_{L,Q}>0.\\ \end{cases} (30)

The MSE in (30) clearly demonstrates that the increase in the number of quantization bits reduces the vector quantization error during the local block compression. Therefore, any increase in the capacity of wireless links will lead to a reduction in the reconstruction error of the global block update at the PS in FedVQCS.

IV-B Parameter Optimization for Local Block Compression

The local block compression process of FedVQCS has three design parameters: (i) the number of quantization bits per entry, Q𝑄Q, (ii) a sparsity level, S𝑆S, and (iii) a dimensionality reduction ratio, R𝑅R. These parameters are closely related to the wireless link capacity as well as the reconstruction error of the global model update at the PS. Motivated by this fact, we optimize the above parameters for minimizing the reconstruction error at the PS under the constraint of the wireless link capacity. In this optimization, we assume that the maximum number of digital bits that can be reliably transmitted from device k𝑘k to the PS in each communication round is given by Ck​N¯>0subscript𝐶𝑘¯𝑁0C_{k}\bar{N}>0. Here, Cksubscript𝐶𝑘C_{k} is determined solely by the wireless link capacity, which can be interpreted as a target compression ratio. For example, if Cksubscript𝐶𝑘C_{k} is given by 0.50.50.5 bits per entry according to the wireless link capacity, the N¯¯𝑁\bar{N}-dimensional local model update needs to be compressed, so that it can be transmitted using only N¯/2¯𝑁2\bar{N}/2 bits in each iteration. We also assume that Cksubscript𝐶𝑘C_{k} is known at both the PS and device k𝑘k. Our strategy for parameter optimization is as follows: We first characterize the best choice of Qk⋆​(Rk)superscriptsubscript𝑄𝑘⋆subscript𝑅𝑘Q_{k}^{\star}(R_{k}) and Sk⋆​(Rk)superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑘⋆subscript𝑅𝑘S_{k}^{\star}(R_{k}) as a function of Rksubscript𝑅𝑘R_{k}. We then determine the best dimensionality reduction ratio Rk⋆superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑘⋆R_{k}^{\star} when Qk=Qk⋆​(Rk)subscript𝑄𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑄𝑘⋆subscript𝑅𝑘Q_{k}=Q_{k}^{\star}(R_{k}) and Sk=Sk⋆​(Rk)subscript𝑆𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑘⋆subscript𝑅𝑘S_{k}=S_{k}^{\star}(R_{k}). In the remainder of this subsection, we omit the indices t𝑡t and b𝑏b for ease of exposition.

IV-B1 Characterization of Qk⋆​(Rk)superscriptsubscript𝑄𝑘⋆subscript𝑅𝑘Q_{k}^{\star}(R_{k}) and Sk⋆​(Rk)superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑘⋆subscript𝑅𝑘S_{k}^{\star}(R_{k})

As discussed in Remark 1, the communication overhead of FedVQCS for device k𝑘k is QkRk​N¯subscript𝑄𝑘subscript𝑅𝑘¯𝑁\frac{Q_{k}}{R_{k}}\bar{N} bits. This overhead needs to be less than or equal to Ck​N¯subscript𝐶𝑘¯𝑁C_{k}\bar{N} for error-free transmission of the compressed local block updates from device k𝑘k to the PS. Therefore, the optimal number of quantization bits to minimize the quantization error for a fixed Rksubscript𝑅𝑘R_{k} is

Qk⋆​(Rk)=Ck​Rk.superscriptsubscript𝑄𝑘⋆subscript𝑅𝑘subscript𝐶𝑘subscript𝑅𝑘\displaystyle Q_{k}^{\star}(R_{k})=C_{k}R_{k}. (31)

To determine the proper sparsity level, we consider the fact that the PS estimates the aggregated block update 𝒈~𝒦g=∑k∈𝒦gρk​𝒈~ksubscript~𝒈subscript𝒦𝑔subscript𝑘subscript𝒦𝑔subscript𝜌𝑘subscript~𝒈𝑘\tilde{\boldsymbol{g}}_{\mathcal{K}_{g}}=\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}_{g}}\rho_{k}\tilde{\boldsymbol{g}}_{k} from its noisy linear observation 𝒚𝒦g=𝑨Rg​𝒈~𝒦g+𝒅𝒦gsubscript𝒚subscript𝒦𝑔subscript𝑨subscript𝑅𝑔subscript~𝒈subscript𝒦𝑔subscript𝒅subscript𝒦𝑔{\boldsymbol{y}}_{\mathcal{K}_{g}}={\boldsymbol{A}}_{R_{g}}\tilde{\boldsymbol{g}}_{\mathcal{K}_{g}}+{\boldsymbol{d}}_{\mathcal{K}_{g}} during the global block reconstruction, where (𝑨Rg)m,n∼𝒩​(0,1)similar-tosubscriptsubscript𝑨subscript𝑅𝑔𝑚𝑛𝒩01({\boldsymbol{A}}_{R_{g}})_{m,n}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,1). Let S~gsubscript~𝑆𝑔\tilde{S}_{g} be the sparsity level of the aggregated block update 𝒈~𝒦gsubscript~𝒈subscript𝒦𝑔\tilde{\boldsymbol{g}}_{\mathcal{K}_{g}}. According to the CS theory [34], a well-established sparse signal recovery algorithm can find a unique solution of the above sparse signal recovery problem with high probability, if

Rk<N2​S~g​log⁡(N/S~g),subscript𝑅𝑘𝑁2subscript~𝑆𝑔𝑁subscript~𝑆𝑔\displaystyle R_{k}<\frac{N}{2\tilde{S}_{g}\log(N/\tilde{S}_{g})}, (32)

for a large N𝑁N, moderately large S~gsubscript~𝑆𝑔\tilde{S}_{g}, and large N/S~g𝑁subscript~𝑆𝑔N/\tilde{S}_{g}. Inspired by this result, we shall use the inequality (32) to check the feasibility of the accurate reconstruction of 𝒈~𝒦gsubscript~𝒈subscript𝒦𝑔\tilde{\boldsymbol{g}}_{\mathcal{K}_{g}} from 𝒚𝒦gsubscript𝒚subscript𝒦𝑔{\boldsymbol{y}}_{\mathcal{K}_{g}}. Recall that during the global block reconstruction process of FedVQCS, the PS groups the local model updates with the same dimensionality reduction ratio (i.e., Rk=Rgsubscript𝑅𝑘subscript𝑅𝑔R_{k}=R_{g}, ∀k∈𝒦gfor-all𝑘subscript𝒦𝑔\forall k\in\mathcal{K}_{g}), as explained in Sec. III-C. Hence, the local block updates that belong to the same group have the same sparsity level (i.e., Sk⋆​(Rk)=Sg⋆superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑘⋆subscript𝑅𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑔⋆S_{k}^{\star}(R_{k})=S_{g}^{\star}, ∀k∈𝒦gfor-all𝑘subscript𝒦𝑔\forall k\in\mathcal{K}_{g}). From this fact, one can easily show that the condition in (32) always holds for all possible 𝒈~𝒦gsubscript~𝒈subscript𝒦𝑔\tilde{\boldsymbol{g}}_{\mathcal{K}_{g}} if Rk<N2​K′​Sk​log⁡(N/(K′​Sk))subscript𝑅𝑘𝑁2superscript𝐾′subscript𝑆𝑘𝑁superscript𝐾′subscript𝑆𝑘R_{k}<\frac{N}{{2K^{\prime}S_{k}\log(N/(K^{\prime}S_{k}))}}. Therefore, we determine the best sparsity level for a fixed Rksubscript𝑅𝑘R_{k} as

Sk⋆​(Rk)=arg⁡max𝑆​S,s.t.​Rk<N2​K′​S​log⁡(N/(K′​S)).formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝑆𝑘⋆subscript𝑅𝑘𝑆𝑆s.t.subscript𝑅𝑘𝑁2superscript𝐾′𝑆𝑁superscript𝐾′𝑆\displaystyle S_{k}^{\star}(R_{k})=\underset{S}{\arg\!\max}~{}S,~{}~{}\text{s.t.}~{}~{}R_{k}<\tfrac{N}{{2K^{\prime}S\log(N/(K^{\prime}S))}}. (33)

IV-B2 Optimization of Rksubscript𝑅𝑘R_{k}

To facilitate the group-wise aggregation strategy explained in Sec. III-C, the dimensionality reduction ratio is assumed to be chosen among a candidate set ℛc={R1c,…,\mathcal{R}^{\rm c}=\{R_{1}^{\rm c},\ldots, RCc:Ric≥1,∀i}R_{C}^{\rm c}:R_{i}^{\rm c}\geq 1,\forall i\}, shared by all the devices. Under this assumption, we aim to find the optimal choice of Rk∈ℛcsubscript𝑅𝑘superscriptℛcR_{k}\in\mathcal{R}^{\rm c} that can minimize the MSE of the global block reconstruction at the PS. This optimization problem can be formulated as

Rk⋆=argminRk∈ℛc𝔼​[‖𝒈¯𝒦g−𝒈^𝒦g‖2],superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑘⋆subscriptargminsubscript𝑅𝑘superscriptℛc𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscript¯𝒈subscript𝒦𝑔subscript^𝒈subscript𝒦𝑔2\displaystyle R_{k}^{\star}=\operatornamewithlimits{argmin}_{R_{k}\in\mathcal{R}^{\rm c}}\mathbb{E}\left[\|\bar{\boldsymbol{g}}_{\mathcal{K}_{g}}-\hat{\boldsymbol{g}}_{\mathcal{K}_{g}}\|^{2}\right], (34)

where 𝒈¯𝒦g=∑k∈𝒦gρk​𝒈¯ksubscript¯𝒈subscript𝒦𝑔subscript𝑘subscript𝒦𝑔subscript𝜌𝑘subscript¯𝒈𝑘\bar{\boldsymbol{g}}_{\mathcal{K}_{g}}=\sum_{k\in\mathcal{K}_{g}}\rho_{k}\bar{\boldsymbol{g}}_{k}, and the expectation is taken with respect to vector quantization error. It is generally challenging for the devices to locally solve the problem in (34) because of a lack of knowledge of the local block updates sent by other devices in the same group. In addition, the estimate of the aggregated block update, 𝒈^𝒦gsubscript^𝒈subscript𝒦𝑔\hat{\boldsymbol{g}}_{\mathcal{K}_{g}}, depends on the sparse signal recovery algorithm chosen at the PS. To overcome these challenges, we consider the ideal scenario in which the PS perfectly finds the support set555The support set of a vector 𝑨𝑨{\boldsymbol{A}} is defined as 𝒯​(𝑨)={i:ai≠0}𝒯𝑨conditional-set𝑖subscript𝑎𝑖0\mathcal{T}({\boldsymbol{A}})=\{i:a_{i}\neq 0\}, which is the index set of the nonzero entries in 𝑨𝑨{\boldsymbol{A}}. of 𝒈~𝒦gsubscript~𝒈subscript𝒦𝑔\tilde{\boldsymbol{g}}_{\mathcal{K}_{g}} by employing a powerful CS recovery algorithm, and, then, it minimizes the squared error ‖𝒈~𝒦g−𝒈^𝒦g‖2superscriptnormsubscript~𝒈subscript𝒦𝑔subscript^𝒈subscript𝒦𝑔2\|\tilde{\boldsymbol{g}}_{\mathcal{K}_{g}}-\hat{\boldsymbol{g}}_{\mathcal{K}_{g}}\|^{2} by solving the sparse signal recovery problem in (13). Under this consideration, we characterize the upper bound of the objective function in (34), as given in the following theorem:

Theorem 2:

Let 𝒈^𝒦gsubscript^𝒈subscript𝒦𝑔\hat{\boldsymbol{g}}_{\mathcal{K}_{g}} be the least squares solution of the sparse recovery problem in (13) obtained with the knowledge of the support set of 𝒈~𝒦gsubscript~𝒈subscript𝒦𝑔\tilde{\boldsymbol{g}}_{\mathcal{K}_{g}}. If 𝔼​[‖𝒅k‖2]=σL,Qk2𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscript𝒅𝑘2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐿subscript𝑄𝑘2\mathbb{E}[\|{\boldsymbol{d}}_{k}\|^{2}]=\sigma_{L,Q_{k}}^{2}, ∀k∈𝒦gfor-all𝑘subscript𝒦𝑔\forall k\in\mathcal{K}_{g}, for a large NRk≫1much-greater-than𝑁subscript𝑅𝑘1\frac{N}{R_{k}}\gg 1 and S~g≫1much-greater-thansubscript~𝑆𝑔1\tilde{S}_{g}\gg 1, the MSE of 𝒈^𝒦gsubscript^𝒈subscript𝒦𝑔\hat{\boldsymbol{g}}_{\mathcal{K}_{g}} is upper bounded as follows:

𝔼​[‖𝒈¯𝒦g−𝒈^𝒦g‖2]𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscript¯𝒈subscript𝒦𝑔subscript^𝒈subscript𝒦𝑔2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[\|\bar{\boldsymbol{g}}_{\mathcal{K}_{g}}-\hat{\boldsymbol{g}}_{\mathcal{K}_{g}}\|^{2}]
