Theorem 2 shows that the upper bound of the global block reconstruction error at the PS can be minimized even if device k∈𝒦g𝑘subscript𝒦𝑔k\in\mathcal{K}_{g} locally minimizes ℰk​(Rk)subscriptℰ𝑘subscript𝑅𝑘\mathcal{E}_{k}(R_{k}). Based on this result, instead of solving (34), we formulate a local optimization problem for device k∈𝒦g𝑘subscript𝒦𝑔k\in\mathcal{K}_{g} as

Rk⋆subscriptsuperscript𝑅⋆𝑘\displaystyle R^{\star}_{k} =argminRk∈ℛc‖𝒈¯k−𝖲𝗉𝖺𝗋𝗌𝖾​(𝒈¯k)‖2+K′​Sk​RkN​L​αk2​σL,Qk2.absentsubscriptargminsubscript𝑅𝑘superscriptℛcsuperscriptnormsubscript¯𝒈𝑘𝖲𝗉𝖺𝗋𝗌𝖾subscript¯𝒈𝑘2superscript𝐾′subscript𝑆𝑘subscript𝑅𝑘𝑁𝐿superscriptsubscript𝛼𝑘2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝐿subscript𝑄𝑘2\displaystyle=\operatornamewithlimits{argmin}_{R_{k}\in\mathcal{R}^{\rm c}}~{}\|\bar{\boldsymbol{g}}_{k}-{\sf Sparse}(\bar{\boldsymbol{g}}_{k})\|^{2}+\frac{K^{\prime}S_{k}R_{k}}{NL\alpha_{k}^{2}}\sigma_{L,Q_{k}}^{2}. (36)

Because device k𝑘k knows the input local block update 𝒈¯ksubscript¯𝒈𝑘\bar{\boldsymbol{g}}_{k} defined in (8), the objective function of (36) can be computed for every Rk∈ℛcsubscript𝑅𝑘superscriptℛcR_{k}\in\mathcal{R}^{\rm c} under the assumptions of Qk=Qk⋆​(Rk)subscript𝑄𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑄𝑘⋆subscript𝑅𝑘Q_{k}=Q_{k}^{\star}(R_{k}) and Sk=Sk⋆​(Rk)subscript𝑆𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑘⋆subscript𝑅𝑘S_{k}=S_{k}^{\star}(R_{k}). Then, by comparing the objective values, device k𝑘k can determine its best dimensionality reduction ratio Rk⋆subscriptsuperscript𝑅⋆𝑘R^{\star}_{k}.

There exists a tradeoff between the first and second terms of the objective function in (36) which can be interpreted as sparsification and reconstruction errors, respectively. The reconstruction error decreases with Rksubscript𝑅𝑘R_{k} because the number of vector quantization bits Qk⋆​(Rk)superscriptsubscript𝑄𝑘⋆subscript𝑅𝑘Q_{k}^{\star}(R_{k}) is an increasing function of Rksubscript𝑅𝑘R_{k}, as can be seen in (31). In contrast, the sparsification error increases with Rksubscript𝑅𝑘R_{k} because the sparsity level Sk⋆​(Rk)superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑘⋆subscript𝑅𝑘S_{k}^{\star}(R_{k}) is a decreasing function of Rksubscript𝑅𝑘R_{k}, as can be seen in (33). Therefore, the optimization problem in (36) allows each device to determine the best parameters for optimizing the tradeoff between the sparsification and reconstruction errors in FedVQCS.

IV-C Convergence Rate Analysis

In this analysis, we characterize the convergence rate of FedVQCS when the SGD algorithm with E=1𝐸1E=1 is employed for updating the parameter vector at the PS. In our analysis, we make the following assumptions not only for mathematical tractability but also for connecting our analysis with the parameter optimization in Sec. IV-B.

Assumption 1: The loss function F​(𝒘)𝐹𝒘F({\boldsymbol{w}}) is β𝛽\beta-smooth and is lower bounded by a constant F​(𝒘⋆)𝐹superscript𝒘⋆F({\boldsymbol{w}}^{\star}), i.e., F​(𝒘)≥F​(𝒘⋆)𝐹𝒘𝐹superscript𝒘⋆F({\boldsymbol{w}})\geq F({\boldsymbol{w}}^{\star}), ∀𝒘∈ℝN¯for-all𝒘superscriptℝ¯𝑁\forall{\boldsymbol{w}}\in\mathbb{R}^{\bar{N}}.

Assumption 2:  For every 𝒘𝒘{\boldsymbol{w}}, the stochastic gradient is unbiased, i.e., 𝔼​[∇Fk(t)​(𝒘)]=∇Fk​(𝒘)𝔼delimited-[]∇superscriptsubscript𝐹𝑘𝑡𝒘∇subscript𝐹𝑘𝒘\mathbb{E}\big{[}\nabla F_{k}^{(t)}({\boldsymbol{w}})\big{]}=\nabla F_{k}({\boldsymbol{w}}), ∀k,tfor-all𝑘𝑡\forall k,t. Also, the variance of the stochastic gradient is bounded by a constant ϵ≥0italic-ϵ0\epsilon\geq 0, i.e., 𝔼​[‖∇Fk(t)​(𝒘)−∇Fk​(𝒘)‖2]≤ϵ𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm∇superscriptsubscript𝐹𝑘𝑡𝒘∇subscript𝐹𝑘𝒘2italic-ϵ\mathbb{E}\big{[}\big{\|}\nabla F_{k}^{(t)}({\boldsymbol{w}})-\nabla F_{k}({\boldsymbol{w}})\big{\|}^{2}\big{]}\leq\epsilon, ∀k,tfor-all𝑘𝑡\forall k,t.

Assumption 3: The squared sparsification error at the device k𝑘k is upper bounded by a constant ζbB≥0subscript𝜁𝑏𝐵0\frac{\zeta_{b}}{B}\geq 0, i.e., 𝔼​[‖𝒈¯k(t,b)−𝒈~k(t,b)‖2]≤ζbB𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript¯𝒈𝑘𝑡𝑏superscriptsubscript~𝒈𝑘𝑡𝑏2subscript𝜁𝑏𝐵\mathbb{E}[\|\bar{\boldsymbol{g}}_{k}^{(t,b)}-\tilde{\boldsymbol{g}}_{k}^{(t,b)}\|^{2}]\leq\frac{\zeta_{b}}{B}, ∀t,bfor-all𝑡𝑏\forall t,b. Also, the squared reconstruction error at the PS is upper bounded by the squared norm of the true block gradient with some constant δb<1subscript𝛿𝑏1\delta_{b}<1, i.e., 𝔼​[‖𝒈~𝒦(t,b)−𝒈^𝒦(t,b)‖2]≤δb​‖∇F(b)​(𝒘(t))‖2𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript~𝒈𝒦𝑡𝑏superscriptsubscript^𝒈𝒦𝑡𝑏2subscript𝛿𝑏superscriptnorm∇superscript𝐹𝑏superscript𝒘𝑡2\mathbb{E}[\|\tilde{\boldsymbol{g}}_{\mathcal{K}}^{(t,b)}-\hat{\boldsymbol{g}}_{\mathcal{K}}^{(t,b)}\|^{2}]\leq\delta_{b}\|\nabla F^{(b)}({\boldsymbol{w}}^{(t)})\|^{2}, ∀t,bfor-all𝑡𝑏\forall t,b, where ∇F(b)​(𝒘(t))∈ℝN∇superscript𝐹𝑏superscript𝒘𝑡superscriptℝ𝑁\nabla F^{(b)}({\boldsymbol{w}}^{(t)})\in\mathbb{R}^{N} is the b𝑏b-th block of ∇F​(𝒘(t))∇𝐹superscript𝒘𝑡\nabla F({\boldsymbol{w}}^{(t)}).

Assumption 3 is particularly relevant to FedVQCS because the parameter optimization of FedVQCS aims at reducing the MSE of the global block update by opportunistically determining the parameters (Q,S,R)𝑄𝑆𝑅(Q,S,R) of the local block compression under the constraint of the wireless link capacity. Note that Assumptions 1 and 2 are commonly adopted for analyzing the convergence rate of FL operating with a family of gradient descent algorithms, as in [13] and [39].

Under Assumptions 1–3, we characterize the convergence rate of FedVQCS with the SGD algorithm. This result is given in the following theorem:

Theorem 3:

Under Assumptions 1–3 with E=1𝐸1E=1, ρk=1Ksubscript𝜌𝑘1𝐾\rho_{k}=\frac{1}{K}, and γ(t)=η(t)=1−maxb⁡δb6​β​(1+maxb⁡δb)​Tsuperscript𝛾𝑡superscript𝜂𝑡1subscript𝑏subscript𝛿𝑏6𝛽1subscript𝑏subscript𝛿𝑏𝑇\gamma^{(t)}=\eta^{(t)}=\frac{1-\max_{b}\delta_{b}}{6\beta(1+\max_{b}\delta_{b})\sqrt{T}}, FedVQCS with the SGD algorithm satisfies the following bound:

𝔼​[1T​∑t=1T‖∇F​(𝒘(t))‖2]𝔼delimited-[]1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇superscriptnorm∇𝐹superscript𝒘𝑡2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\Bigg{[}\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\|\nabla F({\boldsymbol{w}}^{(t)})\|^{2}\Bigg{]}
≤1T​[24​β​(1+maxb⁡δb)(1−maxb⁡δb)2​{F​(𝒘(1))−F​(𝒘⋆)}+ϵ]+maxb⁡ζb18​T.absent1𝑇delimited-[]24𝛽1subscript𝑏subscript𝛿𝑏superscript1subscript𝑏subscript𝛿𝑏2𝐹superscript𝒘1𝐹superscript𝒘⋆italic-ϵsubscript𝑏subscript𝜁𝑏18𝑇\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{\sqrt{T}}\Big{[}\tfrac{24\beta(1+\max_{b}\delta_{b})}{(1-\max_{b}\delta_{b})^{2}}\{F({\boldsymbol{w}}^{(1)})-F({\boldsymbol{w}}^{\star})\}+\epsilon\Big{]}+\frac{\max_{b}\zeta_{b}}{18T}. (37)
Proof:

See Appendix C. ∎

Theorem 3 demonstrates that FedVQCS converges to a stationary point of the loss function if Assumptions 1–3 hold. This theorem also shows that the convergence rate of FedVQCS has the order of 𝒪​(1T)𝒪1𝑇\mathcal{O}\big{(}\frac{1}{\sqrt{T}}\big{)}, which is the same as that of a classical FL framework for a non-convex loss function [39]. Furthermore, the convergence speed of FedVQCS is shown to improve as both δbsubscript𝛿𝑏\delta_{b} and ζbsubscript𝜁𝑏\zeta_{b} decrease. This result implies that our parameter optimization in Sec. IV-B is effective for improving the convergence speed.

V Simulation Results and Analysis

In this section, we demonstrate the superiority of FedVQCS over existing FL frameworks, using simulations. We assume that the communication overhead allowed for transmitting the local model update at device k𝑘k is given by Cksubscript𝐶𝑘C_{k} bits per local model entry. Under this assumption, we consider two communication scenarios: (i) homogeneous and (ii) heterogeneous. In the homogeneous scenario, we set Ck=C¯subscript𝐶𝑘¯𝐶C_{k}=\bar{C}, ∀k∈𝒦for-all𝑘𝒦\forall k\in\mathcal{K}, to model the wireless links with the same capacity; whereas, in the heterogeneous scenario, we uniformly draw Cksubscript𝐶𝑘C_{k} from a pre-defined set 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} to model the wireless links with different capacities.

In this simulation, we consider FL for an image classification task using the publicly accessible MNIST [28] and FEMNIST [29] datasets. Details of the learning scenarios for each dataset are described below.

  • •

    MNIST: The global model is set to be a fully-connected neural network that consists of 784784784 input nodes, a single hidden layer with 202020 hidden nodes, and 101010 output nodes. The activation functions of the hidden layer and the output layer are set to the rectified linear unit (ReLU) and the softmax function, respectively. For the global model training at the PS, the ADAM optimizer in [40] with an initial learning rate 0.010.010.01 is adopted. Each local training dataset is determined by randomly selecting 500500500 training data samples from two classes. For the local model training at each device, the mini-batch SGD algorithm with a learning rate 0.010.010.01 is adopted with |𝒟k(t,e)|=10superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘𝑡𝑒10|\mathcal{D}_{k}^{(t,e)}|=10 and E=3𝐸3E=3. For both the ADAM optimizer and the mini-batch SGD algorithm, the cross-entropy loss function is used. For the MNIST dataset, we set the number of wireless devices to K=75𝐾75K=75 and the number of communication rounds to T=50𝑇50T=50.

  • •

    FEMNIST: The global model is set to be a variant ResNet-181818, which has about 1.1×1071.1superscript1071.1\times 10^{7} trainable parameters. For the original ResNet-181818 in [8], we modify the input, the first convolution, and output layers to match the dimensions of FEMNIST dataset. We also replace the batch normalization layers to the layer normalization layers to improve the performance of the global model [41]. For the global model training at the PS, the ADAM optimizer in [40] with an initial learning rate 5×10−55superscript1055\times 10^{-5} is adopted. For the local model training at each device, the mini-batch SGD algorithm with a learning rate 10−7superscript10710^{-7} is adopted with |𝒟k(t,e)|=500superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘𝑡𝑒500|\mathcal{D}_{k}^{(t,e)}|=500 and E=5𝐸5E=5. Each local training dataset is determined by randomly grouping 202020 writers in FEMNIST dataset, and thus turn 200200200 writers into 101010 devices [42, 43]. For both the ADAM optimizer and the mini-batch SGD algorithm, the cross-entropy loss function is used. For the FEMNIST dataset, we set the number of wireless devices to K=10𝐾10K=10 and the number of communication rounds to T=50𝑇50T=50.

For performance comparisons, we consider the following FL baselines:

  • •

    Perfect reconstruction: This framework assumes lossless transmission of the local model updates from the wireless devices to the PS without compression, as described in Sec. II-A.

  • •

    FedVQCS: FedVQCS is the proposed FL framework summarized in Procedure 1. In this framework, the vector quantizer in Sec. IV-A is adopted. The parameters of FedVQCS are optimized as described in Sec. IV-B when the candidate set is ℛc={1.5+0.25​r:r∈{0,1,…,6}}superscriptℛcconditional-set1.50.25𝑟𝑟01…6\mathcal{R}^{\rm c}=\big{\{}1.5+0.25r:r\in\{0,1,\ldots,6\}\big{\}}. To be specific, the optimal dimensionality reduction ratio Rk⋆superscriptsubscript𝑅𝑘⋆R_{k}^{\star} is chosen among ℛcsuperscriptℛc\mathcal{R}^{\rm c} according to the criterion in (36), while the optimal quantization bit Qk⋆superscriptsubscript𝑄𝑘⋆Q_{k}^{\star} and the optimal sparsity level Sk⋆superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑘⋆S_{k}^{\star} are determined from (31) and (33), respectively. The EM-GAMP algorithm in [18] is employed as a sparse signal recovery algorithm during the global block update reconstruction. The dimension of a subvector for vector quantization is set to be the largest integer, L𝐿L, such that L​2Qs⋆≤215𝐿superscript2superscriptsubscript𝑄s⋆superscript215L2^{Q_{\rm s}^{\star}}\leq 2^{15}, where Qs⋆superscriptsubscript𝑄s⋆Q_{\rm s}^{\star} is the optimal number of shape quantization bits.

  • •

    ScalarQCS: ScalarQCS is the communication-efficient FL framework developed in [18] when Qk=2subscript𝑄𝑘2Q_{k}=2, Rk=2/Cksubscript𝑅𝑘2subscript𝐶𝑘R_{k}=2/C_{k}, and Sk=max⁡(1,Sk⋆​(Rk))subscript𝑆𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑘⋆subscript𝑅𝑘S_{k}=\max\big{(}1,S_{k}^{\star}(R_{k})\big{)}. The aggregate-and-estimate strategy in [18] is adopted for the global block update reconstruction.

  • •

    HighVQ: HighVQ is the communication-efficient FL framework developed in [15] when Qk=Cksubscript𝑄𝑘subscript𝐶𝑘Q_{k}=C_{k}. The dimension of each partition for vector quantization is set to be the largest integer, L𝐿L, such that L​2Ck​L≤215𝐿superscript2subscript𝐶𝑘𝐿superscript215L2^{C_{k}L}\leq 2^{15} for device k𝑘k.

  • •

    D-DSGD: D-DSGD is the communication-efficient FL framework developed in [22]. The number of the nonzero entries for device k𝑘k is set to be Sksubscript𝑆𝑘S_{k} such that Ck​N¯=log2⁡(N¯Sk)+33subscript𝐶𝑘¯𝑁subscript2¯𝑁subscript𝑆𝑘33C_{k}\bar{N}=\log_{2}\big{(}\begin{smallmatrix}\bar{N}\\ S_{k}\end{smallmatrix}\big{)}+33.

For FedVQCS and ScalarQCS, we set (G,B)=(25,10)𝐺𝐵2510(G,B)=(25,10) for the MNIST dataset and (G,B)=(5,9152)𝐺𝐵59152(G,B)=(5,9152) for the FEMNIST dataset. Note that under this setting, the number of the devices in group is not larger than 333, while N𝑁N is not larger than 200020002000. For D-DSGD, we adjust the input data values of the MNIST training and test data samples so that these values are between 00 and 111. Except for this, we normalize the input data values of the training and test data samples using the mean and standard deviation of each dataset [44].

In Fig. 3, we compare the classification accuracy of different FL frameworks in the homogeneous scenario. Fig. 3 shows that for both the MNIST and FEMNIST datasets, FedVQCS provides more than a 2.4%percent2.42.4\% increase in classification accuracy compared to the existing communication-efficient FL frameworks when the communication overhead of the local model update transmission is 0.1 bit per local model entry. Meanwhile, the results on the MNIST dataset demonstrate that FedVQCS with a 0.1-bit overhead per local model entry yields only a 2%percent22\% decrease in classification accuracy compared to the perfect reconstruction which requires a 32-bit overhead per local model entry for perfect transmission of the local model updates. This result demonstrates that FedVQCS enables an accurate reconstruction of the global model update at the PS, while significantly reducing the communication overhead of FL. Fig. 3 also shows that FedVQCS is more robust against the decrease in the communication overhead allowed for the devices, when compared with the existing FL frameworks.

In Fig. 4, we compare the classification accuracy of different FL frameworks in the heterogeneous scenario with various average communication overheads. In this simulation, we set 𝒞={0.05,0.1,0.2,0.25}𝒞0.050.10.20.25\mathcal{C}=\{0.05,0.1,0.2,0.25\} for 𝔼​[Ck]=0.15𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐶𝑘0.15\mathbb{E}[C_{k}]=0.15, 𝒞={0.05,0.15,0.35,0.45}𝒞0.050.150.350.45\mathcal{C}=\{0.05,0.15,0.35,0.45\} for 𝔼​[Ck]=0.25𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐶𝑘0.25\mathbb{E}[C_{k}]=0.25, and 𝒞={0.2,0.3,0.4,0.5}𝒞0.20.30.40.5\mathcal{C}=\{0.2,0.3,0.4,0.5\} for 𝔼​[Ck]=0.35𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐶𝑘0.35\mathbb{E}[C_{k}]=0.35. Fig. 4 shows that FedVQCS converges to the highest classification accuracy among the communication-efficient FL frameworks, irrespective of the average communication overhead allowed for the devices. These results imply that FedVQCS effectively adjusts the local model update compression at each device based on its link capacity, while reducing the reconstruction error at the PS.

In Fig. 5, we compare the classification accuracies of FedVQCS with and without the parameter optimization in Sec. IV-B for the MNIST dataset in the homogeneous scenario with Ck=0.07subscript𝐶𝑘0.07C_{k}=0.07. Without parameter optimization, we set Rk=Rsubscript𝑅𝑘𝑅R_{k}=R, Qk=Qk⋆​(R)subscript𝑄𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑄𝑘⋆𝑅Q_{k}=Q_{k}^{\star}(R), and Sk=Sk⋆​(R)subscript𝑆𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑆𝑘⋆𝑅S_{k}=S_{k}^{\star}(R), ∀k∈𝒦for-all𝑘𝒦\forall k\in\mathcal{K}. Fig. 5 shows that FedVQCS with the optimized parameters provides a 1.8%percent1.81.8\% increase in classification accuracy compared to FedVQCS with the worst-case parameters (i.e., R=3𝑅3R=3 case). This result demonstrates that our parameter optimization effectively improves the accuracy of global model reconstruction at the PS in FedVQCS. This result is also consistent with the convergence rate analysis in Theorem 3 which demonstrated that the convergence rate improves as the reconstruction error of the global model update at the PS decreases.

In Fig. 6, we compare the classification accuracy of FedVQCS with that of ScalarQCS for different numbers of groups for the MNIST dataset in the homogeneous scenario with Ck=0.1subscript𝐶𝑘0.1C_{k}=0.1. Fig. 6 shows that FedVQCS outperforms ScalarQCS regardless of the number of the groups. Because these two frameworks have a similar global model reconstruction process, the performance gain of FedVQCS over ScalarQCS is attributed to the use of vector quantization instead of scalar quantization. From Fig. 6, we can also observe that the classification accuracies of both frameworks decrease as G𝐺G decreases. Because the computational complexity of the global model reconstruction process also decreases with G𝐺G, the result in Fig. 6 shows that the performance-complexity tradeoff associated with these frameworks can be controlled by adjusting the number of groups.

VI Conclusion

In this paper, we have presented a novel framework for communication-efficient wireless FL. We have shown that our framework significantly reduces the communication overhead of FL by leveraging both vector quantization and CS-based dimensionality reduction for compressing the local model updates at the wireless devices. Another key feature of our framework is that the devices can locally optimize the compression parameters in order to minimize the reconstruction error of a global model update at the PS under the constraint of the wireless link capacity. We have also demonstrated both analytically and numerically that our compression parameter optimization improves the convergence rate of FL. An important direction of future research is to optimize the learning rate of a training algorithm employed at the PS by taking into account the reconstruction error at the PS. Another promising research direction is to develop dynamic device scheduling and resource allocation strategies for the presented framework by considering the real-world radio resources available in a wireless network.
